INTRODUCTION\nTwelve years ago, Secretary of Defense Leon Panetta was the first to warn of the threat of a cyber \"Pearl Harbor\" or a cyber \"9/11\" terrorist attack, as well as of cyber threats that \"could virtually paralyze the nation.\"¹ Ten years later, Costa Rica was the victim of an unprecedented assault when ransomware cyber attacks virtually paralyzed it to the extent that its president had to officially declare a state of emergency. Albania, a NATO member State, severed diplomatic ties with Iran following Iranian cyber attacks that aimed to cripple Albania's online government services and leak sensitive emails and government data.² In an era of global interconnectedness, the risks are borderless, severe global effects are at stake, and even sensitive national security computer control systems can be targeted. Unsurprisingly, these threatening cyber capabilities carry strategic implications for geopolitics, including the \"Great Power Competition.\"³ This rivalry between powers, coupled with deep ideological disparities (democratic versus authoritarian values), has become a major obstacle in ensuring global safety and stability in and through cyberspace. Rather than reaching a universal consensus on binding comprehensive international regulation, the international community, influenced by the conflicting views of competing powers, has made little headway. Consensus has been limited to agreeing in principle that international law, particularly the UN Charter, is applicable to cyberspace and concluding eleven voluntary, non-binding norms of responsible State behavior in cyberspace (the \"List of Non-Binding\n1. This ambiguity provides major powers with enough leeway to strive for “cyberspace superiority”⁵ while ostensibly maintaining their reputation as law-abiding nations. On the other side of the fence, China, Russia, Iran, and North Korea (CRINK) have exploited this ambiguity and the technical characteristics of cyberspace for advancing their interests. Under such circumstances, the List of Non-Binding Norms’s effectiveness in changing State behavior and the level of State compliance are low. Moreover, the norms’ effectiveness and State compliance are influenced by the extent to which the norms and the process of application are perceived as legitimate, as well as the degree to which the outcomes align with the expectations derived from these norms and processes.⁶\n⁴. Pollack eds., 2013); Timothy Meyer, *How Compliance Understates Effectiveness*, 108 AMERICAN JOURNAL OF INTERNATIONAL LAW UNBOUND 93 (2014).\nCollective Attribution in Cyberspace\nVol. 103\nAgainst the backdrop of this normative ambiguity and inherent legal uncertainty, the process of attributing State responsibility stands as an essential and exclusive measure to hold specific States accountable for violating the norms of the List. To gauge the extent to which the United States has developed its attribution policy in the past decade, it is worth revisiting Secretary Panetta's 2012 remarks.⁷ In response to two consecutive destructive cyber attacks, he hinted at the improving technological capabilities to address the attribution problem by identifying cyber attackers and attributing responsibility.⁸ Therefore, “potential aggressors should be aware that the United States has the capacity to locate them and to hold them accountable for their actions that may try to harm America.”⁹ However, it is important to note that neither the United States nor the direct victim States, Saudi Arabia and Qatar, officially attributed responsibility for these cyber attacks to Iran, even though its responsibility has been widely accepted.\nIn fact, my previous published research on State practice in cyberspace between 2012 and 2018, co-authored with Yuval Shany, revealed that explicit official attributions were the exception during that period.¹⁰ Nonetheless, the last two attribution determinations addressed in that study indicated a shift from national official attributions toward collective attributions.¹¹\nIndeed, the collective activity of nations in attributing responsibility to States for irresponsible behavior in cyberspace and in responding to such behavior has become a vital component of the deterrence pillar within the U.S. National Cyber Strategy. The United Kingdom, the closest ally to the United States, has endorsed this strategy.¹²\n7. Panetta, supra note 1. The backdrop of Panetta’s remarks—two destructive cyber attacks in August 2012 targeting and paralyzing Aramco, the largest oil company in the world, located in Saudi Arabia, and RasGas, the second-biggest liquefied natural gas company in Qatar.\n8. In this article “cyber attacks,” “cyber operations,” and “cyber activities” are used interchangeably, but the article focuses on politically motivated incidents, that is, cyber attacks conducted by States through their official organs and agents or through third parties as proxies.\n9. Panetta, supra note 1.\n10. Dan Efrony &amp; Yuval Shany, *A Rule Book on the Shelf? Tallinn Manual 2.0 on Cyberoperations and Subsequent State Practice*, 112 AMERICAN JOURNAL OF INTERNATIONAL LAW 583, 634 (2018).\n11. Id. at 586.\n12. THE WHITE HOUSE, NATIONAL CYBER STRATEGY OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA 21 (2018); see also Jeremy Hunt, UK Foreign Sec’y, Deterrence in the Cyber Age Speech at Glasgow University (Mar. 7, 2019), https://www.gov.uk/government/speech\nInternational Law Studies\n2024\nThis article aims to evaluate the collective attribution policy and process implementation—primarily by the United States and its close allies—and its effectiveness over the years through mapping and examining all the collective attribution determinations announced from the first one (WannaCry) through January 1, 2024. For the purposes of this article, “official attribution” refers to any public, verbal or non-verbal, statement made by a senior official of a State authorized to formally attribute responsibility for a given cyber attack to another State. Heads of State, ministries of foreign affairs, and other ministries whose mandate includes cybersecurity naturally hold such authority. As such, official attributions must be both public and political. Therefore, in this research, indictments filed or unsealed by the U.S. Department of Justice, personal sanctions imposed by the U.S. Department of Treasury, advisory alerts issued by the U.S. Cybersecurity &amp; Infrastructure Security Agency, and other reports from national law enforcement agencies, cannot on their own constitute an official attribution of responsibility to a State. However, they can certainly provide grounds for the United States and other States to attribute responsibility officially and explicitly to another State. Subsequently, the term “collective attribution” refers to a State’s official attribution joined by at least one other nation’s official attribution. Alternately, it shall apply if the State’s official attribution announcement is accompanied simultaneously and in coordination with another State officially announcing a response to the same cyber operation through indictments, sanctions, or joint advisories.\nThis article evaluates whether the collective attribution process and its outcomes can be perceived as legitimate and credible by the international community, including impartial, nonaligned States. Furthermore, it evaluates whether this process has become a crucial component in effectively holding States accountable for violating the List of Non-Binding Norms and in deterring States from such violations. Analyzing these and related issues requires a sound understanding of the official attribution process in practice, focusing on identifying legitimacy and credibility disparities, and researching the collective attributions announced so far. The article is built exclusively upon open-source intelligence.\nThe article continues as follows. Part II describes the official attribution process, differentiating between technological, legal, and political attributions and discussing the reluctance of States to officially attribute re\nes/deterrence-in-the-cyber-age-speech-by-the-foreign-secretary (presenting the United Kingdom’s deterrence strategy, mirroring the U.S. approach).\n274\nCollective Attribution in Cyberspace\nVol. 103\nsponsibility. Part III explores major aspects of the American attribution process, the most influential one, excluding the internal division of labor among the U.S. national security and law enforcement entities. It includes five sections that characterize the American attribution process, each of which could affect the extent to which the process's outcomes would be perceived as credible and legitimate. The first is the instrumental ambiguity the United States has embraced in the absence of a binding international convention, which has an adverse effect on transparency and source-based legitimacy. The subsequent three sections—intelligence-based attribution, attribution by indictment, and the private sector's role in ensuring cyber security—are important for mitigating the challenge of transparency but are still insufficient to ensure credibility and legitimacy. The fifth section explores collaboration between the private sector, particularly American corporations, including the most powerful tech platforms globally, and U.S. national security entities responsible for the American attribution process. This all-American collaboration may raise serious concerns among non-American constituencies about the credibility and legitimacy of the U.S. attribution process and its outcomes. Part IV delves into the specific collective attributions starting with three international initiatives. Two of these, initially planned to catalyze and empower collective attributions, have already faded, while the third initiative holds potential as part of a solution. Section IV(B) is a table that succinctly presents fourteen cases of collective attribution, spanning from the first collective attribution on December 19, 2017, until January 1, 2024. A detailed overview of these fourteen cases appears as an annex at the end of this article. Section IV(C) analyzes the findings. Part V concludes.\n## II. OFFICIAL ATTRIBUTION\nMuch has been written in the literature about detecting, identifying, and attributing responsibility for cyber attacks to a culprit State by the official authorities of the victim State.¹³ Only a decade ago, the prevalent view con\n¹³. CLEMENT GUITTON, INSIDE THE ENEMY'S COMPUTER: IDENTIFYING CYBER ATTACKERS (Aug. 2017); see also Thomas Rid &amp; Ben Buchanan, Attributing Cyber Attacks, 38 JOURNAL OF STRATEGIC STUDIES 4 (2015) (proposing the “Q Model”); Herbert Lin, Attribution of Malicious Cyber Incidents: From Soup to Nuts, 70 JOURNAL OF INTERNATIONAL AFFAIRS 75 (2016); OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR OF NATIONAL INTELLIGENCE, A GUIDE TO CYBER ATTRIBUTION (Sept. 14, 2018), https://dl.icdst.org/pdfs/files3/db004a6f55f96c056a23fc4efc6a23ac.pdf.\nInternational Law Studies\n2024\nsidered this task almost unattainable, verging on a mission impossible.¹⁴ Cyber technical features that allow full anonymity and transboundary connectivity make it exceedingly difficult to promptly detect and identify with complete certainty who is responsible for disruptive or destructive cyber operations, as opposed to comparable operations in the physical domain. Any savvy hacker, let alone a government or State-sponsored one, is capable of manipulatively concealing their identity and astutely misdirecting would-be trackers. Nonetheless, today, the prevalent view has changed; while still challenging and occasionally time-consuming, it has become more feasible to uncover the true facts. Advanced cyber forensic investigative capabilities, which cyber power States and powerful cyber security firms possess, may enable them to unmask authentic technical features of a cyber attack, including the computers involved in the operation and their geographic locations. They may even identify the hacker or group of hackers according to their authentic technological fingerprints, precluding manipulative attempts to deceive and mislead the investigators. Such technical findings may lead to a technical attribution,¹⁵ which mostly lacks credible responses to the following questions: Who, in fact, stands behind the hackers who conducted the given cyber attack? What are the real motives? Was a State involved, and to what extent?¹⁶\nCompleting the missing pieces of the puzzle by gathering evidence from all-source intelligence may fill the probability gaps, enabling States to officially attribute responsibility to another State for unlawful cyber operations targeting other States. Nevertheless, this task remains easier said than done, particularly considering the challenges associated with legally attributing State responsibility, which I will address in a subsequent article.\n14. Compare Nicholas Tsagourias, Cyberattacks, Self-Defence and the Problem of Attribution, 17 JOURNAL OF CONFLICT AND SECURITY LAW 229 (2012), with Panetta, supra note 1.\n15. The term “technical attribution” is somehow misleading since technical attribution mostly does not result in clear attribution of responsibility to a State. At most, it is an estimated attribution of responsibility to a group of hackers based on the findings of tactics, techniques, and procedures. Reviewing the methods and techniques used in the discourse of technical investigations is beyond the scope of this article. For more information on this topic, see D.D. Clark &amp; S. Landau, Untangling Attribution, in PROCEEDINGS OF A WORKSHOP ON DETERING CYBERATTACKS: INFORMING STRATEGIES AND DEVELOPING OPTIONS FOR U.S. POLICY 25, 25–40 (2010); see also sources cited in supra note 13.\n16. Kristen Eichensehr, The Law &amp; Politics of Cyberattack Attribution, 67 UCLA LAW REVIEW 520 (2020); see also Lin, supra note 13, at 8–19 (emphasizing the need for all-source intelligence); GUITTON, supra note 13, at 36.\nCollective Attribution in Cyberspace\nVol. 103\nEvery victim State thoroughly analyzes the information collected from all sources, including from cyber power State allies and cyber security and tech firms, to conclude whether the information is well-established and sufficient for a definite attribution. Even if the information includes enough evidence for attribution, the victim State's political leadership must weigh a wide range of strategic considerations and then determine whether to officially attribute responsibility; what level of transparency to implement; whether to retaliate, and if so, how, covertly or overtly; and which type of response would be perceived as lawful or legitimate in the given circumstances?\nA State might avoid an official attribution to preclude risks and actions that do not coincide with its national security interests, such as jeopardizing intelligence sources, disclosing intelligence gaps that the victim State may have pertaining to its rivals' cyber capabilities, exposing the victim State's confidential cyber capabilities, and averting the significant risk of misattribution, which could lead policymakers to wrongly engage in retribution and escalation.\nFurthermore, by refraining from public attribution, the victim State eliminates public pressure for retaliation and may lead the culprit State to believe it has not been detected. This strategy could allow the victim State to covertly monitor the operation and gather valuable intelligence about its rival's cyber capabilities. Additionally, it could facilitate the detection of additional covert operations employing the same cyber techniques while also considering disinformation or deception operations.[17] Moreover, powers that still obscure their political and legal approaches to pending cyber legal questions—such as the boundaries of legitimate \"cyber espionage,\" the clear threshold for constituting a prohibited \"use of force\" and a prohibited intervention, and how \"territorial sovereignty\" should be applied in cyberspace—might hesitate to officially attribute responsibility in specific circumstances. This is because such attribution could reduce the legal ambiguity these States have embraced to preserve their technological edge and maintain strategic leeway.\nTherefore, attribution is primarily a political decision relying on prudent and thorough discretion on whether to officially attribute responsibil-\n17. Gil Baram &amp; Udi Sommer, Covert or Not Covert: National Strategies During Cyber Conflict, 11TH INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON CYBER CONFLICT 3 (2019), https://ccdcoe.org/uploads/2019/06/Art_11_Covert-or-Not-Covert.pdf (noting that victim States have at least four options to consider: full or partial concealment of the attack and publicizing the attack with or without public attribution).\nInternational Law Studies\n2024\nity to another State under given circumstances. The attribution determination is not necessarily contingent on legal proceedings. $^{18}$  The reasonableness of such an ex ante attribution must be assessed on a case-by-case basis and under no binding requirements of transparency and standard of proof. $^{19}$  Thus, it is no more than a public political denunciation, especially when not accompanied by legal claims and countermeasures. Although the attribution may rely on technical findings and additional evidence from any other source of information, it does not necessarily have to withstand the legal scrutiny that a formal legal attribution of State responsibility might face.\nAs noted above, the difficulties of legally attributing State responsibility will be addressed in a subsequent article. For the purposes of the present article, it is worth noting the following: pursuant to the rules of State responsibility, a State harmed by a malicious cyber operation that is willing to officially attribute responsibility to an attacking State and has a legal justification for a lawful response, must meet two cumulative requirements.[20] The first is to indicate a breach of an international rule that binds States under circumstances like those of the cyber incident in question. This might be controversial as long as international cyber law remains in its embryonic stage and the extent and conditions under which customary rules of international law would apply to cyberspace as binding law continue to be open-ended. The second requirement is to identify a perpetrator suspected of breaching the international rule and substantiate their connection—either as an official agent or as a proxy—to a specific State.\nThus far, none of the attributing States have faced demands to legally prove their attribution statement within the framework of judicial or quasi-judicial proceedings. To date, this process has never been applied in court with respect to cyber incidents.\n# A. Reluctance of States to Officially Attribute Responsibility\nDuring recent decades, States have conducted hundreds or thousands of disruptive and destructive cyber attacks either through their official organs and agents or through proxies. Only in a tiny fraction of cases did States officially attribute responsibility to other States based on technical and all-source intelligence. At times, these official attributions also relied on private sector contributions through confidential or nonconfidential reports of relevant companies. At least until the second half of 2017, victim States would refrain from officially attributing responsibility to another State unless they were amid an armed conflict, during which they often blamed\nOF INTERNATIONAL ADJUDICATION (Cesare P.R. However, the U.S. Administration declined to follow this path, likely due to political and national security considerations. One possible explanation might have been the relentless Russian attempts to meddle in the tense September 26, 2021, German elections and the urgent need to stop those attempts. The second, and so far, the last, exceptional official attribution reinforced this estimation. On September 5, 2021, Germany officially attributed to Russia responsibility for cyber attacks conducted by a cyber group dubbed Ghostwriter, even though the evidence was not “hard” but “reliable information” that established “suspicions” against the GRU.³⁶ This triggered an official diplomatic protest and an investigation, yet no one waited for its final findings due to the short time left (three weeks) until the elections.\nIt is noteworthy that this was the first report of a State officially holding another State accountable for a cyber attack and responding with an official diplomatic protest, relying on information that merely met the level of “suspicions.” Apparently, this sort of cutting corners or lowering the bar of evidence stemmed from the urgent need to stop or deter Russia from interfering with the quickly approaching German elections race. This coincides with the principle, according to which an official attribution is a purely political decision, not necessarily a legal attribution that should meet specific legal requirements. The attribution determination does not rely on full transparency or even a significant degree of transparency, let alone the ability to withstand any external, independent, and impartial scrutiny. This provides room for questioning the credibility and legitimacy of the official attribution. Part III addresses several segments of the U.S. national attribution process, examining how they may have potential positive or negative impacts on the legitimacy and credibility of the collective process and its outcomes.\n## III. EVALUATING ASPECTS OF LEGITIMACY AND CREDIBILITY IN THE ATTRIBUTION PROCESS\nNational security interests dictate confidentiality regarding classified intelligence, including information about sensitive cyber tools, detection capabilities, and military cyber capabilities. However, in the absence of multinational, impartial, legal, and professional scrutiny regarding the accuracy and lawfulness of the official attribution in any given situation, attributing States must be mindful of how various constituencies could perceive their attribution statements. Without accepted clear and binding rules, these statements may not be viewed as lawful. Nevertheless, there is a concerted effort to influence public opinion through enhancing the legitimacy of the attribution process. If successful, this could bolster the effectiveness of its attribution determinations.\nThe following sections address five segments that characterize the American attribution process, each of which could positively or negatively influence how the outcomes of the process are perceived for credibility and\n37. UNC1151 Assessed with High Confidence to Have Links to Belarus, Ghostwriter Campaign Aligned with Belarusian Government Interests, MANDIANT (Nov. 16, 2021), https://www.mandiant.com/resources/unc1151-linked-to-belarus-government.\nInternational Law Studies\n2024\nlegitimacy. Except for attribution by indictment, these segments are relevant to the UK attribution process, as well as those of other like-minded cyber power States. Unlike authoritarian regimes, these States have embraced the courses of action described in the following sections to contend with the demand for transparency while striving to achieve the best result for their own national security interests.\n# A. An Instrumental Ambiguity\nCyberspace's unique technological attributes produce opportunities for cyber power States to surreptitiously generate significant strategic gains through covert cyber operations, thereby minimizing the risk of being held accountable for breaching the law and harming their reputation as law abiding States. On the one hand, States strive to evade legal responsibility by distancing themselves from any factual or legal linkage to the malicious cyber operations in question. On the other hand, national security interests dictate the non-disclosure of classified information for both victim and attacking States. However, such data could help them substantiate arguments to strengthen or dismiss relevant accusations.\nAs mentioned above, States, particularly the leading powers involved in the Great Power Competition, have embraced instrumental ambiguity, including maintaining silence on questions related to the interpretation and application of recognized principles and rules of customary international law in cyberspace. The primary motive behind this policy is to retain a sufficient margin of maneuver to enable the protection and promotion of strategic national interests in the rapidly evolving cybersphere. This policy of ambiguity inherently leads to accountability gaps that the most influential cyber power States, like the United States, are reluctant to resolve. Nevertheless, it is crucial for these States to play a decisive role in shaping international cyber law in a manner and at a time that aligns best with their national security interests. Unsurprisingly, they seek to avoid situations requiring an independent, international, judicial forum, such as the International Court of Justice, to resolve legal ambiguities surrounding State conduct in cyberspace.\nNotwithstanding the growing number of States that have clarified, albeit partially and cautiously, their views about a limited number of legal questions, the policy of ambiguity still prevails. The policy influences policymakers when considering whether to officially attribute responsibility and\nCollective Attribution in Cyberspace\nVol. 103\nwhen considering how transparent to be regarding relevant evidence and legal arguments.³⁹\nOfficial attribution regarding cyber incidents in itself does not eliminate the need for transparency. This requirement is inherent in the legal obligation to substantiate State responsibility in both non-cyber and cyber incidents.⁴⁰ Transparency is essential to legitimize the official attribution by reflecting its “right process” through its process-based and outcome-based legitimacy.⁴¹ In the absence of accessible international judicial or quasi-judicial forums, as well as an impartial international monitoring institution, conflicting States might seek to influence the final “judgment” of the “international court of legitimacy.” This type of influence often involves legitimizing one side while delegitimizing the other. To achieve this, States should enhance transparency regarding their findings and, more importantly, with respect to processes and procedures undertaken. This includes ensuring that they align with Thomas Franck’s concept of the “right process.”⁴² The degree to which this transparency is genuine and comprehensive serves to strengthen their arguments in attributing responsibility or denying it, respectively.\nRelying solely on the investigative role of the United States or the United Kingdom, coupled with limited transparency and unwillingness to disclose persuasive evidence, opens the door to plausible deniability. Excluding independent, objective, and multinational experts, as well as representatives from other States, from participating in the attribution process also provides grounds for criticizing the integrity of the process. The absence of these persons may raise concerns about the process being flawed, unfounded, politically biased, and non-transparent, thus, not credible or legit-\n³⁹. These concerns are particularly significant given the common reality of blanket denials by accused States.\nShould a State that officially attributes State responsibility for wrongful acts in cyberspace evade disclosure of the evidence and confidential information upon which the attribution and, if undertaken, retribution rely?\nThe first to address this question, in November 2016, was Brian Egan, U.S. State Department Legal Advisor, who noted that States are not required to act with full transparency when attributing responsibility to another State.43 Since then, a growing number of States have embraced a legal stance that denies the obligation to reveal classified evidence prior to attribution or countermeasures, making the extent of disclosure a matter of policy that often involves complex considerations.44 Striking a balance between accountability, diplomatic relations, and, most importantly, national security, including the strategic interest of maintaining instrumental ambiguity, remains a significant challenge in the evolving landscape of cyberspace governance. Yet simply prioritizing national security interests to the extent of excluding transparency may erode trust in the attribution statement. Nevertheless, powers like the United States and the United Kingdom, which possess advanced cyber capabilities and robust intelligence, do not hesitate to base their attribution claims solely on their intelligence assessment system, thereby preserving confidentiality and national security interests.\n## B. Intelligence-Based Attribution\nThe term \"intelligence assessment\" usually does not imply absolute certainty nor admissibility in court but rather the degree of certainty and credibility with which a certain factual narrative should be perceived, using the qualifiers of the national intelligence community about high, moderate, or low likelihood/certainty of the narrative as described in the attribution statement.45 The degree of certainty obviously depends on the level of trust in the information collected and the extent to which it is considered reliable and credible. The more reliable and credible, the higher the degree of cer\n43. Brian Egan, Legal Advisor, U.S. Dept. of State, Remarks on International Law and Stability in Cyberspace to Berkeley Law School (Nov. 10, 2016), in DIGEST OF UNITED STATES PRACTICE IN INTERNATIONAL LAW 815 (2016).\n44. Cyber Law Toolkit, supra note 39.\n45. OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR OF NATIONAL INTELLIGENCE, supra note 13.\nCollective Attribution in Cyberspace\nVol. 103\ntainty, and the more that information may whet the policymakers' appetites to officially attribute responsibility to the culprit State if additional political considerations justify such an attribution.\nUp to this point, the United States and the United Kingdom have adhered to this official format of attribution, responding publicly with measures such as diplomatic démarche and sanctions when attributions were based on an intelligence assessment of high certainty and the interest of national security allowed a limited transparency to withstand an appropriate judicial or administrative review. By endorsing this practice, both States have averted compromising sensitive intelligence to justify their official attribution and retorsion, which is a response within the prerogative of any State. Even if the attribution of State responsibility proves to be mistaken, the response undertaken remains lawful, albeit unfriendly, and is often reciprocally retaliated. Nevertheless, covert cyber operations remain a viable response, either alongside or instead of retorsions. However, if exposed, their legality would inevitably be challenged.\nCritics of intelligence assessment as major grounds for attribution argue that it relies on criteria that \"may at best amount to circumstantial evidence,\" far below the evidentiary standards used in courts.[46] This allows States to manipulate cases to fit preconceived narratives and embody political agendas; it may lead to misleading results involving the misinterpretation of information influenced by what later turns out to be a false conception.[47]\nNone of the official American attributions since 2014, nor any of the collective attributions that the United States and the United Kingdom have announced since 2017, have corroborated this criticism. Both States have officially attributed responsibility relying on their intelligence and a high degree of certainty (\"almost certainly\"). Some of these attributions have also referred to open-source investigative reports and technological findings of tech and cyber security companies, mostly American, as discussed below. Others were also followed, months or even years later, by detailed American indictments delivering the message that they rely on sufficient and admissible evidence. However, only a limited number of States have been sufficiently convinced or politically motivated to officially adopt and join these attribution statements. Even these States did not do so because they truly participated in the attribution process itself or obtained access to\n46. GUITTON, supra note 13, at 98–99.\n47. Id.\n287\nInternational Law Studies\n2024\nhighly classified and credible intelligence materials supporting the intelligence assessment. The “Five Eyes” intelligence-sharing alliance (“FVEY”)—United States, United Kingdom, Australia, Canada, and New Zealand—is exceptional. However, the United States shares its classified intelligence with its partners in this alliance and occasionally extends this practice to additional allied States such as France, Germany, and Japan.\nNevertheless, the investigation team determining the attribution remains exclusively American. The limited number of participating States might also indicate that those States, which the United States and the United Kingdom interchangeably have not allowed to participate in the process or share classified information, are hesitant to blindly trust American or British intelligence assessments. Considering that the United States is the driving force behind these attributions and that its rivals, such as the CRINK States, are consistently on the receiving end underscores the importance of challenging the credibility of the process and its outcomes.\nConcurrently with intelligence-based attribution, the United States has endorsed, on its own, another method to mitigate the demand for transparency. This is attribution by indictment (\"naming and shaming\"). The next section will demonstrate that, despite its relative transparency, attribution by indictment has not proven a benchmark for credibility and trust.\n## C. Attribution by Indictment\nUntil now, the United States stands as the first and only State to “name and shame” by indicting, in absentia, foreign State-sponsored hackers, mostly citizens of the CRINK. They have been accused of breaching the U.S. Code by committing cybercrimes against Americans and U.S. entities. These indictments provide an opportunity to describe their worldwide malicious cyber activity. They include declassified information about unlawful cyber activities, shedding light on relevant State responsibility. This responsibility stems from the fact that, while committing the unlawful activities, the defendants were either State agents (such as soldiers, officers, or other government officials) or third parties under the State’s control, direction, instruction, or empowered by the law of that State to exercise elements of governmental authority.⁴⁸\nHowever, indicting unlawful combatants, such as spies captured during peacetime or armed conflict while conducting their mission in the territory\n⁴⁸. Articles on State Responsibility, supra note 20, arts. 4–5, 8.\nCollective Attribution in Cyberspace\nVol. 103\nof the accusing State, is unexceptional and reflects customary international law.⁴⁹ Nevertheless, indicting, in absentia, defendants identified as official agents of a foreign State for remotely hacking and damaging, during peacetime, targets located in the territory of the accusing State is both exceptional and unprecedented.⁵⁰ This could be acceptable if the hacks were criminally motivated and could not be attributed to a specific State, according to the Articles on State Responsibility.\nThe U.S. Attorney General, William Barr, admitted that “traditional military and intelligence activity is a separate sphere of conduct that ought not be subject to domestic criminal law,” with the recognized exception noted above of charging intelligence officers operating undercover in the United States.⁵¹ Barr introduced new and unprecedented exceptions such as State-sponsored computer intrusions “for the purpose of intellectual property theft for the use of [the Chinese] private sector, bank robbery, and interfering with our democratic elections” and “deliberate, indiscriminate theft of vast amounts of sensitive personal data of civilians,”⁵² as occurred in the case of hacking Equifax. In Barr’s words, such cases “cannot be countenanced.”⁵³ In fact, such cases have led to the submission of indictments in deviation from the customary principles of international law and the recognized principle of criminal responsibility. One scholar labeled this a “judicialized attribution,” a new tool to convey more concrete and less political attribution focusing on the evidence and lawfulness of the behavior according to domestic law rather than international law.⁵⁴ This is despite the fact that both the superiors and subordinates who followed their orders purportedly committed the attributed crimes remotely from\n49. In fact, the process is controlled and guided by the federal prosecutor of the case rather than a judge. Moreover, the indictments may also rely on evidence from American tech and cybersecurity companies, which, as explored below, closely collaborate with local governmental authorities. As mentioned above, a growing number of States have publicly endorsed the view that States attributing responsibility do not need to disclose classified evidence. However, neither provides transparent evidence that could withstand external and impartial scrutiny, subsequently substantiating the attribution determinations and ensuring their credibility.\nThe next section delves into the significant role played by the private sector, particularly in the United States, illustrating how private sector collaboration with the U.S. Government may enhance the level of transparency in determining and announcing official attributions. However, concurrently, it may raise concerns about the legitimacy and credibility of such attributions.\n## D. The Role of the Private Sector\nThe private sector, through its major tech and cyber security firms, plays a key role in the attribution process, as it possesses significant tech capabilities for detecting and investigating cyber incidents. Western companies, mostly American, such as Meta (Facebook, WhatsApp, Messenger, Instagram), Microsoft (Windows, Azure), Amazon (Amazon Web Services), Alphabet (Google, YouTube), X (previously Twitter), Apple, Hewlett Packard, and Verizon, dominate cyberspace in both software and hardware, encompassing global social media, big data, cloud services, artificial intelligence, computer operating systems, and search engines. Each of these realms is a playground where any vulnerability exposed by third parties could be exploited, posing serious threats to the company's reputation and business success. Thus, these companies invest vast resources to consistently lead in technology, developing cutting-edge capabilities to detect, investigate, and thwart any threat, regardless of its motives through in-house cyber threat intelligence teams. Moreover, global tech platforms, in particular, have achieved worldwide dominance and maintain a formidable presence in cyberspace, a level of control that State cyber powers, including a cyber superpower like the United States, struggle to maintain.⁶⁷ Additional-\n⁶⁶. Nevertheless, voices are growing, as embodied in proposals and decisions, calling to limit the global impact of\nCollective Attribution in Cyberspace\nVol. 103\nly, civil society organizations, such as the Citizen Lab, which focus mostly on safeguarding human rights from malicious cyber operations, and leading multinational cyber security firms, such as Mandiant, CrowdStrike, Kaspersky, and Symantec, have been evolving their cyber security expertise to successfully detect, thwart, and investigate any harmful cyber operation from any source.⁶⁸\nThat said, victim States less capable in cyberspace would seek immediate assistance from a cyber power ally to confront any hostile cyber operation or campaign and investigate accountability. Typically, such aid would involve collaboration with domestic or global cyber security and tech companies that have become major players in the field of cyber threat intelligence, holding capabilities that may even exceed those of government intelligence agencies.⁶⁹ These capabilities are crucial for gathering, processing, and analyzing technological findings to promptly establish situational awareness for the State's decision-makers.⁷⁰ Multiple firms have already engaged in such activities and provided their client States, and sometimes the public, with relatively prompt and detailed technical reports. These reports may include clear-cut technical evidence to detect and distinctly identify the perpetrators. However, technical attribution alone is not always sufficient for attributing responsibility with a full or high level of certainty. The Russia-Ukraine war has raised a serious debate regarding the unique and unprecedented role that powerful tech platforms, like Starlink and Microsoft, have independently realized during this war. Addressing this intriguing issue is beyond the scope of this article.\n⁶⁸ Kristen E. Eichensehr, Public-Private Cybersecurity, 95 TEXAS LAW REVIEW 467 (2017) (describing the roles of the U.S. Government and the private sector in the context of contending with international cybersecurity threats, including botnet takedowns, remediating zero-day vulnerabilities, and attributing cyber intrusions to States or Statesponsored cyber attackers); see also Jennifer Maddocks, Outsourcing of Governmental Functions in Contemporary Conflict: Rethinking the Issue of Attribution, 59 VIRGINIA JOURNAL OF INTERNATIONAL LAW 47, 68 (2019) (discussing the option of attributing to States responsibility for private companies' activities by virtue of Article 5 of the Articles on State Responsibility).\n⁶⁹ Kris Oosthoek &amp; Christian Doerr, Cyber Threat Intelligence: A Product Without a Process?, 34 INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF INTELLIGENCE AND COUNTERINTELLIGENCE 300, 302 (2020).\n⁷⁰ Id. at 301; see also Nicholas Tsagourias &amp; Michael Farrell, Cyber Attribution: Technical and Legal Approaches and Challenges, 31 EUROPEAN JOURNAL OF INTERNATIONAL LAW 941 (2020); Sasha Romanosky &amp; Benjamin Boudreaux, Private-Sector Attribution of Cyber Incidents: Benefits and Risks to the U.S. Government, 34 INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF INTELLIGENCE AND COUNTERINTELLIGENCE 463 (2021); Eichensehr, supra note 16, 547–50.\nInternational Law Studies\n2024\nnoted above, the decision whether to name the culprit State and officially attribute responsibility is purely political, and concerned vendor firms tend to comply with this.71 Experience thus far indicates that when tech and cyber security companies detect anomalies and even malicious cyber operations through their routine preventive and researching cyber security activities, rather than as a part of a service ordered by the victim State, they generally avoid involvement in what might be inter-State conflicts. Unless biased (as discussed in the following section), they tend to classify the hostile cyber operation as sophisticated, suggesting potential execution by either an anonymous cyber power State or hackers sponsored by such a State.72 Technical attributions are usually faster, more detailed, and more transparent than official attributions, which are, to a greater extent restricted by confidentiality and related considerations of national security. This course of action characterizes private sector companies and has a double motivation, rooted both in business interests (business-based) and adherence to norms (norms-based). Naturally, the firms that are driven by business motives are interested in branding themselves—domestically and internationally—as the leading and most reliable professional actors in their fields, ahead of any existing or potential competitor. Such branding should go hand in hand with positioning the firms as prioritizing and aligning with values of universal human rights and other major norms included in the List of Non-Binding Norms, which reflect responsible peacetime State behavior in cyberspace. In this context, national and international responsibility to secure human life and well-being in an unregulated and risky cyberspace, at least by sharing relevant information with the public, has become a matter of utmost importance.\nPrivate sector firms that investigate and expose malicious cyber tools and methodologies used in specific cyber attacks publish their findings to\n71. More importantly, this helps enhance their cyber security capabilities and their preparedness to detect and thwart such threats. At the same time, such information may raise suspicions that a specific cyber attack is, in fact, an act of State or a State-sponsored operation. Occasionally, a private sector technological investigation may lead to complete attribution, including identification of the culprit State or its official organ.73 This occurs despite the general business orientation to avoid involvement in inter-State conflicts. Such attribution is a proper alternative to the official attribution that the victim State may avoid due to its strategic and national security considerations, as noted above. In such circumstances, the company's explicit technological attribution may influence international public opinion, delegitimizing the suspected State in the eyes of other States. Furthermore, any State could become a victim of similar unacceptable behavior at any time, and each may use such attributions to politically attribute responsibility to the suspected State.\nThe following section addresses the collaboration U.S. national security agencies maintain with relevant American private sector companies, including in the context of the attribution process. Naturally, this partnership is not completely transparent, nor is it exclusive to the United States. It also encompasses attribution determinations, raising doubts about the extent to which these determinations should be perceived as credible and legitimate through the lens of neutral observers.\n## E. Private Sector Collaboration with Governments\nA voluntary contribution by private sector companies to national efforts to defend the country from external threats is common, self-evident, and not limited to wartime. Thus, authorities of States cooperate and maintain close and confidential ties with leading domestic entities in the private sector in every relevant field, including health, transportation, tech-industry, telecommunications, and cybersecurity. Liberal democracies, as opposed to authoritarian regimes, maintain such cooperation within the boundaries of law. The Snowden disclosures of June 2013 about secret National Security Agency (NSA) operations involving American telecom companies rein\n73. Mandiant, for instance, was the first to attribute APT1 to China in a detailed attribution report based on technical findings and other, not necessarily technical, information gathered by the firm. CrowdStrike was the first to attribute responsibility to Russia for the Democratic National Committee hack during the 2016 U.S. elections.\nInternational Law Studies\n2024\nforce the perception that companies in established democracies assist their governments \"even above and beyond their legal obligations to do so.\"74 Conversely, authoritarian regimes are guided primarily by their self-interest in ensuring the regime's security and sustainability and would, therefore, do whatever it takes to secure their regime. As the end justifies the means, not even universal human rights would pose a barrier. As a corollary, the private sector companies, including foreign multinational platform companies operating under such regimes, must comply with their orders and restrictive regulations. Otherwise, the companies might pay excessive prices, which could include restricting, and even terminating, voluntarily or nonvoluntarily, their operations in the countries concerned.75\nDue to the Great Power Competition and the intensifying tension, particularly in cyberspace, the U.S. Administration has preemptively imposed a Federal ban on procuring software and services from certain Chinese and Russian tech and software companies that may secretly serve as long arms for both competitor powers in the sensitive fields of cyberspace and telecommunications. Eichensehr, supra notes 67, at 68.\nCollective Attribution in Cyberspace\nVol. 103\nScholars have already examined different facets of Private Sector-U.S. Government collaboration.⁸³ For the purposes of this article, it is important to focus on whether the collaboration of American multinational tech platforms with the American national security authorities undermines or, on the contrary, bolsters the credibility of the U.S. attribution process.⁸⁴ This is especially significant considering its key role in the collective attributions detailed in the following Part.\nUndoubtedly, such collaboration bolsters capabilities for revealing the truth behind any given cyber incident and establishing a solid attribution claim. However, in the absence of an independent international mechanism of accountability, the American attribution process, including the said collaboration, should withstand the scrutiny of its primary target constituency—the international community or international public opinion. Naturally, national security aspects of this collaboration remain confidential, though not always entirely so. Similarly, transparency may partially manifest itself in three dimensions: unexpected and undesired transparency—by leakers and whistleblowers; forced and balanced transparency—exclusively by virtue of judicial warrants that balance between conflicted interests, usually national security on one side and human rights on the other; and coordinated transparency—at the initiative of federal authorities in concert with the respective tech platforms.\n⁸³. Given the experience to date, should this policy be welcomed or re-evaluated? That is the question discussed below.\n## IV. COLLECTIVE ATTRIBUTION\nIn 2017, in the wake of two developments—the collapse of the fifth round of the UN–GGE and large-scale cyber attacks such as WannaCry and NotPetya—the United States and the United Kingdom extended the policy of official attribution to a new pattern of collective attribution aimed at deterring States from violating norms of responsible State behavior in cyberspace. As the table below shows, all the reviewed collective attributions, except one, relied on the national attribution processes of the United States and the United Kingdom regarding cyber attacks that targeted them or their allies. Prior to discussing the cumulative experience of the collective attribution concept per se, and to illustrate the complete picture in this context, the first section of this Part reviews three international initiatives that the United States introduced to deter States and advance responsible peacetime State behavior in cyberspace in conjunction with holding States accountable by relying on the concept of collective attribution.\n## A. Collective Attribution Within International Initiatives\nDespite the legal obstacles and instrumental ambiguity noted above, the List of Non-Binding Norms remains the main international instrument to hold States accountable for wrongdoing that violates the voluntary norms of responsible peacetime State behavior in cyberspace. This accountability is essential for establishing effective deterrence, while the attribution determination is a keystone for invoking accountability in any given incident.\nIn its updated National Cyber Strategy, the Trump Administration announced the launch of the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative to re\n2023), https://www.theregister.com/2023/09/20/huawei_china_claims/ (reporting on post of China’s Ministry of State Security on WeChat, in which the United States is accused of running cyber attacks and espionage for more than ten years against China, Russia, and forty-five other countries and regions, and of implanting backdoors in equipment and software and using American global technology brands to monitor and steal data).\nCollective Attribution in Cyberspace\nVol. 103\ninforce efforts to deter States from violating the List of Non-Binding Norms through “official attribution,” “collective attribution,” a “naming and shaming” strategy, and through a “collective response” by jointly imposing sanctions against States accused of violating the List.¹⁰⁹ Ultimately, no State has officially announced that it will join the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative, not even the closest ally of the United States, the United Kingdom, although it promptly endorsed the pillars of the U.S. strategy.¹¹⁰ The International Cyber Deterrence Initiative has not evolved into an effective international initiative, such as the Proliferation Security Initiative¹¹¹ or the International Counter Ransomware Initiative discussed below. In fact, the United States never officially launched the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative, and senior U.S. officials have rarely referred to it.¹¹²\nThe literature includes only one study that references the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative, focusing solely on the collective response rather than the credible collective attribution that is implicitly a prerequisite to any collective response.¹¹³ Within this study, the scholar examined the policy embraced by each State party in the FVEY in building offensive cyber capabilities. The findings reveal that the FVEY States, excluding New Zealand, align with the approach of responding firmly to irresponsible State behavior in cyberspace. Additionally, those States have developed the offensive cyber capabilities needed, among others, to uphold such a policy. The scholar concludes by suggesting that the FVEY and other like-minded allies enhance the credibility of their deterrent collective response\n¹⁰⁹. THE WHITE HOUSE, supra note 12.\n¹¹⁰. Admittedly, the findings of this article bolster the conclusion that the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative never materialized as an active initiative for collectively imposing costs on States violating the List of Non-Binding Norms.\nIn September 2019, the United States, Australia, and the Netherlands co-sponsored a new international initiative and, together with twenty-five other States, issued a Joint Statement on Advancing Responsible State Behavior in Cyberspace.[114] This statement includes a commitment to hold States accountable, that is, to collectively attribute State responsibility for violating the List of Non-Binding Norms. It also calls on States to transparently impose costs under international law. The Advancing Responsible State Behavior in Cyberspace has only been invoked once since 2019. On February 21, 2020, fifteen out of the twenty-eight Advancing Responsible State Behavior in Cyberspace partner States teamed up with Georgia and attributed responsibility to Russia for a disruptive cyber campaign conducted by the GRU. They politically denounced Russia and demanded it comply with the List of Non-Binding Norms.[115]\nTwo months later, on April 16, 2020, the Czech Republic's National Cyber and Information Security Agency warned of a real threat of serious cyber attacks against its healthcare sector amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. The day after, the U.S. Secretary of State released a statement in which he mentioned the Statement on Advancing Responsible State Behavior in Cyberspace framework and warned against conducting such dangerous cyber attacks or knowingly allowing them: \"Anyone that engages in such an action should expect consequences.\"[116] Eventually, the threat was not real\n114. Moreover, neither the Czech nor the American authorities were transparent enough to convince observers that this was not a shot in the dark, but rather a successful preventive response to a credible and imminent threat.\nAs indicated above, neither the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative nor the Joint Statement on Advancing Responsible State Behavior in Cyberspace has gained political significance. Unsurprisingly, the anticipation that States beyond the closest allies of the United States would align with American or British attribution statements and impose various costs—political, economic, and otherwise—proved unfounded. It appears that the United States has relinquished both initiatives and, together with its partners in the FVEY, has remained focused on the collective attribution endeavor, as detailed in the following section.\nHowever, beyond the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative and Advancing Responsible State Behavior in Cyberspace, in October 2021 the United States established an international initiative to counter the threat of ransomware cyber operations, which the Biden Administration has recently defined as a threat to U.S. national security.¹¹⁸ Although this International Counter Ransomware Initiative¹¹⁹ deals exclusively with criminally motivated ransomware cyber operations, it remains relevant in the context of the present discussion of collective attribution by States. This is because its primary goal is to uphold multinational cooperation to counteract ransomware threats and bolster both resiliency and deterrence. To achieve this, the International Counter Ransomware Initiative strengthens cooperation by facilitating the sharing of information and professional expertise among the participating States and private sector companies. More crucially for the focus of this article is its collaborative effort to detect and identify hackers or hacker groups involved in ransomware attacks, whether independently\n¹¹⁷. In other words, the Initiative establishes and maintains multinational collaboration to detect, identify, and attribute responsibility for malicious cyber attacks.\nSince its establishment in 2021, the International Counter Ransomware Initiative has consistently increased its membership and actively devised strategies to confront the substantial threat.[120] Despite these efforts, the Initiative has not yet urged its members to collectively attribute responsibility to States involved in conducting ransomware cyber attacks, either through their official State organs or third parties. Similarly, the Initiative has not yet led to the attribution of responsibility to States that tolerate recurring cyber attacks initiated from their sovereign territories.\nRussia has already demonstrated that Russian ransomware gangs, such as REvil, may thrive or decline depending on the regime's willingness to cooperate.[121] Ultimately, increasing collaboration among the International Counter Ransomware Initiative States may encompass holding States accountable for ransomware cyber operations, even when initiated and directed from their sovereign territory, violating the due diligence principle. Apart from addressing the legal complexities associated with such accusations, the Initiative's parties may also seek to attribute responsibility and hold States accountable for what they have already defined as prohibited \"irresponsible behaviors.\"\nNonetheless, when upheld by a common multinational investigative team, the resulting attribution is collective and certainly more legitimate and credible. (reporting about indications of REvil's revival a month after the United States unilaterally stopped the Russian American communication channel on cybersecurity in the wake of the Russian war on Ukraine).\nCollective Attribution in Cyberspace\nVol. 103\nCronos.¹²² An international law enforcement task force led by the UK's National Crime Agency and the FBI and consisting of eleven International Counter Ransomware Initiative member States (United States, United Kingdom, France, Japan, Switzerland, Canada, Australia, Sweden, Netherlands, Finland, and Germany) successfully executed an international disruption campaign, taking control of the website and services (ransomware-as-a-service) of LockBit. This criminal hacking group is recognized as the world's most harmful cybercrime group. The outcomes of this operation included the seizure in three countries of LockBit's data exfiltration infrastructure by members of the task force. Two LockBit operatives were arrested in coordination with Europol. The U.S. Department of Justice unsealed indictments against two Russian citizens for conspiring to commit LockBit ransomware attacks. The Department of Justice also announced that two defendants responsible for using LockBit to execute ransomware attacks were in custody and would face trial in the United States. The lessons learned from this experience could prove valuable for the United States and the United Kingdom in addressing the pitfalls of the current collective attribution process and response. This could serve as a test case demonstrating how successful cooperation between International Counter Ransomware Initiative member States can be in fighting criminally motivated, as well as politically motivated, cybercrime. Thus, the Initiative, in particular, may serve as an appropriate pilot for exploring optional solutions to better tackle the challenges associated with collective attributions and responses. More importantly, such solutions would enhance State accountability and the effectiveness of attributions in changing State behavior in cyberspace.\n## B. Analysis: Remarks and Insights\n### 1. Remarks on the Process in Practice\n#### i. Five Eyes' Key Role\nDespite being an intelligence alliance, the FVEY partners are not obligated to full transparency between their intelligence agencies. However, they do share intelligence at a level of confidentiality not extended to other allies. This alliance is the core of the collective attribution strategy, while the United States and the United Kingdom are its driving forces. They cooperate in investigating wide-scale cyber attacks by exchanging confidential information and mobilizing, separately or in conjunction, to assist victim\n¹²⁵. The FVEY's attribution announcements are made concurrently and in coordination.¹²⁸ However, they rely on sharing classified information, not on the findings of an independent FVEY multinational investigative team or any other form of international investigative mechanism. Like the decision to officially attribute State responsibility itself, endorsing an official attribution made by another State is a political prerogative for each sovereign State, which may announce it as its own official attribution. Such attribution determinations rely on various cumulative considerations, including the accuracy and credibility of evidence shared with all partners. While Canada has, thus far, actively participated in all collective attributions initiated by the United States and the United Kingdom, Australia refrained in three instances (Cases 6, 7, 13) and New Zealand in four (Cases 6, 7, 11, 13). Neither New Zealand nor Australia publicly justified their decision to refrain in each of these instances.\n## ii. EU and NATO Attributions or Partial Attribution Statements\nThe EU, representing twenty-seven European States, has had a notable practice of declarations in support of collective attributions. Thus far, it participated in eleven out of fourteen collective attributions, while NATO participated in six out of these same eleven attributions. However, the attribution statements on behalf of the EU and NATO could hardly be considered fully attributive. Instead, they may be perceived as a partial attribution of responsibility, making a limited contribution to the collective attribution strategy.\n¹²⁷. See, e.g., Cases 5, 13, supra Section IV(B) (providing examples in which the United Kingdom assisted the Georgian authorities in contending with and investigating the malicious cyber campaign); see Press Release, U.S. Embassy Tirana, Committed Partners in Cyberspace: U.S. Concludes First Defensive Hunt Operation in Albania (Mar. 23, 2023), https://al.usembassy.gov/committed-partners-in-cyberspace-u-s-concludes-first-defensive-hunt-operation-in-albania/.\n¹²⁸. At times, the dates on statements from Australia and New Zealand may not match those of other FVEY partners. However, the announcements are most likely published simultaneously with those of the FVEY partners, and at times the incompatibility of dates may be due to the different time zones.\nInternational Law Studies\n2024\nThe following are some probable causes driving this partial level of EU and NATO participation in collective attributions:\n(a) The EU and NATO do not possess independent cyber investigative capabilities. Both rely heavily on more capable allies, namely the United States and the United Kingdom. Furthermore, EU and NATO member States, like Sweden, the Netherlands, Estonia, Austria, France, and Germany, each of which possess independent investigative capabilities, allegedly provide the EU security authorities with “deficient and incomplete” evidence in order to preserve the confidentiality of their cyber capabilities.¹²⁹ To date, the EU has joined an official attribution initiated by one of its members only once (Case 10), and the attribution is highly questionable. NATO has never joined an attribution that was not initiated by the United States or the United Kingdom. It is worth noting that both States also face challenges in implementing a high degree of transparency with the EU security authorities due to the sensitivity and confidentiality of their intelligence sources. Nevertheless, the direct involvement of the United States and the United Kingdom in investigating cyber attacks appears to be a differentiating factor, possibly explaining why both, along with Canada and New Zealand, refrained from participating in the EU and Germany collective attribution (Case 10), while Australia settled for expressing solidarity.¹³⁰\n(b) The EU and NATO have joined collective attributions through brief declarations or statements issued on behalf of both Councils. The wording of these official declarations or statements must be cautious and measured to achieve unanimity within a truly brief period. Typically, they condemn the cyber attack in question, express concerns about it, and show solidarity with the affected States. The EU and NATO choose to avoid any explicit attribution of responsibility to the CRINK States. At the same time, the United States and the United Kingdom explicitly attribute responsibility primarily to specific official agents or organs of any State within the\n¹²⁹. The EU and NATO refrain from attributing responsibility even to CRINK's official entities, such as intelligence agencies and national security institutions, which some of the U.S. or UK attribution determinations refer to in detail. In Case 9, for instance, the North Atlantic Council's statement acknowledges official statements made by its members—United States, United Kingdom, and Canada—attributing to China responsibility for compromising the Microsoft Exchange Server. The statement continues expressing solidarity with those who were affected, calling on \"all states, including China,\" to uphold their international commitments and \"act responsibly, including in cyberspace.\"131 Similarly, the EU's declaration refrains from explicitly attributing responsibility to China for malicious cyber activities, as opposed to the FVEY attribution statements.132 Instead, the EU \"strongly denounces\" these malicious cyber activities, urging China to comply with norms of responsible State behavior and prevent the use of its territory for such activities.133 The EU approach further differs from the FVEY by emphasizing adherence to the List of Non-Binding Norms, including due diligence, rather than strictly assigning State responsibility. However, challenges arise when applying due diligence to cyberspace, given uncertainties about its compatibility with the specific circumstances and the contested nature of its application in this\n131. Incoherency and Lack of Standardization\nThe collective FVEY attributions reviewed indicated incoherency, a lack of standardization, and an absence of transparent criteria, primarily in selecting which cyber operations the United States or the United Kingdom would lead the FVEY to collectively attribute. Likewise, there is uncertainty about the criteria guiding the EU and NATO in determining which attributions to publicly support, all while navigating possible political storms.[136] Questions persist regarding the degree of certainty justifying an attribution in the first place and how to measure that degree.[137] Further considerations involve the timing and format of coordinated announcements, whether through verbal statements by senior government officials (such as heads of states, relevant ministers, and senior officials from the U.S. National Security Council and their counterparts in other States), or by written statements of an authorized governmental agency or ministry, or both in concert.\n134. Doubtful Credibility\nThere are only a small number of official attributions and an even smaller number of collective attributions that do not rely primarily on the American attribution process. The credibility and legitimacy deficiencies of the American attribution process, as highlighted in the previous Part—such as ambiguous normativity, limited transparency, and reliance on potentially biased American investigative teams instead of impartial multinational teams—persist unresolved in collective attributions. These issues may deter States from participating in explicit attributions as opposed to partial attributions. The cases reviewed indicate that States' willingness to participate in collective attributions based on the outcome of another State's national attribution process is limited, even if this system belongs to a cyber power State such as the United States or the United Kingdom. Consequently, the deterrence and effectiveness of such attributions also remain low.¹⁴⁴\nCase 11 requires a closer look as it raises serious doubts about the credibility of both the American and British attribution processes, and whether their outcomes are credible and persuasive enough to encourage a growing number of States to participate in such collective attributions. In this case, the Ukrainian Government suspected Russia just because it was then the only State interested in destabilizing Ukraine.¹⁴⁵ Just forty-eight hours later, the United States and the United Kingdom provided the fastest attribution determination each of these allies had ever announced. Shaping “Rules of the Road”\nAiming to bolster deterrence, the United States and the United Kingdom initiated the collective attribution process as a response to attacking States in cyberspace.[150] However, in the absence of normative clarity, attribution announcements refer to unacceptable and irresponsible State behavior, rather than specifying international rules or norms allegedly breached by the given cyber attack. Thus, the policy implemented usually involves delegitimization (\"naming and shaming\") and retorsions, lawful measures that can be imposed without the need for detailed legal justification. The objective is to shape \"rules of the road\" by specifying instances of unacceptable cyber activity on case-by-case bases and to develop State practice accordingly. This involves instilling among the entire community of nations the perspectives of collective attributors regarding which cyber operations may constitute irresponsible State behavior.[151] Such activities would be deemed irresponsible State behavior when conducted by official State agents or entities, as well as by hacking groups affiliated with these entities, operating under their instruction, direction, or control.[152] Although the List of Non-Binding Norms does not refer to economic or national security espionage, bilateral agreements and multinational commitments prohibit the theft of intellectual property (IP), trade secrets, and business information to gain competitive commercial advantages.[153] Such multinational commitments may be an additional source for shaping \"rules of the road\" in the commitments' context.\nThe cases reviewed can be categorized into subcategories representing types of irresponsible State behavior. Each subcategory has the potential to form specific prohibitions on certain types of conduct, akin to rules of the road. Below is a classification of the cases reviewed into four subcategories,\n150. If so, it would constitute a clear violation of the non-intervention norm, rendering it an unlawful activity. Since the UK Attorney General proposed this approach, the United States and the United Kingdom have jointly undertaken only two additional collective attributions (Cases 13, 14). However, instead of attributing unlawful cyber activities to Iran and Russia, the UK Foreign Secretary characterized Iranian actions as “reckless” and “unacceptable”¹⁵⁹ and Russian actions as “completely unacceptable.”¹⁶⁰ This aligns with the established practice of the FVEY, as evidenced in the cases reviewed. Nevertheless, adopting and implementing the British Attorney General’s integrated legal and political approach within the collective attribution strategy could potentially confer a more binding aspect to norms, such as the prohibitions on intervention and use of force, sovereignty of States, due diligence, and the boundaries of permitted espionage. This might create incentives for States, mindful of their reputation as responsible and law-abiding entities, to adhere to these norms as interpreted and applied to cyberspace. Sanctions as a Collective Response\nAnother dimension of the legality of the attributed violation lies in the appropriate response. As mentioned earlier, both the FVEY and the EU confine their responses to retorsions, such as travel bans and asset freezing, undertaken against the entities and persons engaged in conducting the malicious cyber attacks in question. The expectation that a collective attribution would prompt retorsions from a high number of participating States, forming an effective collective deterrent response, has not materialized as of yet.¹⁶¹ Nevertheless, such a response has become a common practice of the United States and to a lesser extent, the EU and the FVEY.\nAt the level of the United States, sanctions are imposed with greater frequency against individuals and entities based on findings and charges detailed in joint advisories or unsealed indictments and law enforcement investigations. Despite the considerable number of sanctioned individuals and entities, many are government personnel and entities associated with the CRINK, and a significant number have also been indicted.¹⁶² While the ultimate goal of sanctions is not to punish but to bring about a positive change in behavior,¹⁶³ this change has not materialized as of yet. At the level of the FVEY partners, the United Kingdom has regulated its own independent cyber related sanctions regime and occasionally imposed sanctions in coordination with the United States.¹⁶⁴ Australia legislated a cyber sanctions law in December 2021. In January 2024, it implemented it for the first time against a Russian cybercriminal found responsible for the Medibank\n¹⁶¹. Ultimately, sanctions are not designed to punish but rather to motivate positive changes in State behavior.¹⁷⁰ Given that the main outlaw States in cyberspace—Russia, Iran, and North Korea—are already subject to extensive multinational sanctions regimes for reasons unrelated to “irresponsible” malicious cyber operations,¹⁷¹ the impact of sanctions imposed as a response to malicious cyber activities is difficult to evaluate decisively. Nevertheless, the increasing frequency and scale of politically motivated cyber operations suggest that the deterring effect of collective attributions, along with retorsions, is weak.¹⁷² Due to the lack of authorized information regarding the outcomes of these sanctions and in the face of persistent politically motivated cyber attacks originating from the same culpable States and orchestrated by their governmental entities, it would not be inaccurate to argue that the effectiveness of this policy has yet to be conclusively demonstrated. Meanwhile, it still has a symbolic, declarative impact needed to emphasize the red lines that States should not cross.\nIn conclusion, at present, collective attribution is no more than the upshot of the national attribution process, mostly American and British, with the addition of evidence sharing with like-minded States, in a manner that imposes no burden on the U.S. or UK intelligence community. The United States and the United Kingdom are always the driving force, while a CRINK State almost always stands on the receiving end. States and alliances participating in collective attributions, particularly the EU and FVEY, do not determine whether to join the attribution through direct involvement in investigative and attribution processes, but rather are influenced by political affiliations and international commitments within international frameworks, such as the G7, G20, and U.S.-EU or UK-EU dialogues. As a result, the collectiveness as implemented in the attribution process does not bolster the credibility of the American or British attribution determinations. This could notably change if the number of States committed to joining the attributions significantly increases, not due to political pressure or other political considerations, but rather due to an enhanced, joint, impartial, transparent, professional, and multinational process as the International Cyber Ransomware Initiative has recently demonstrated within its limited\n¹⁷⁰.
