For the purposes of this article, it is important to focus on whether the collaboration of American multinational tech platforms with the American national security authorities undermines or, on the contrary, bolsters the credibility of the U.S. attribution process. This is especially significant considering its key role in the collective attributions detailed in the following Part.\nUndoubtedly, such collaboration bolsters capabilities for revealing the truth behind any given cyber incident and establishing a solid attribution claim. Naturally, national security aspects of this collaboration remain confidential, though not always entirely so. Given the experience to date, should this policy be welcomed or re-evaluated? That is the question discussed below.\n## IV. COLLECTIVE ATTRIBUTION\nIn 2017, in the wake of two developments—the collapse of the fifth round of the UN–GGE and large-scale cyber attacks such as WannaCry and NotPetya—the United States and the United Kingdom extended the policy of official attribution to a new pattern of collective attribution aimed at deterring States from violating norms of responsible State behavior in cyberspace. As the table below shows, all the reviewed collective attributions, except one, relied on the national attribution processes of the United States and the United Kingdom regarding cyber attacks that targeted them or their allies. Prior to discussing the cumulative experience of the collective attribution concept per se, and to illustrate the complete picture in this context, the first section of this Part reviews three international initiatives that the United States introduced to deter States and advance responsible peacetime State behavior in cyberspace in conjunction with holding States accountable by relying on the concept of collective attribution.\n## A. Collective Attribution Within International Initiatives\nDespite the legal obstacles and instrumental ambiguity noted above, the List of Non-Binding Norms remains the main international instrument to hold States accountable for wrongdoing that violates the voluntary norms of responsible peacetime State behavior in cyberspace. This accountability is essential for establishing effective deterrence, while the attribution determination is a keystone for invoking accountability in any given incident.\nIn its updated National Cyber Strategy, the Trump Administration announced the launch of the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative to re\n2023), https://www.theregister.com/2023/09/20/huawei_china_claims/ (reporting on post of China’s Ministry of State Security on WeChat, in which the United States is accused of running cyber attacks and espionage for more than ten years against China, Russia, and forty-five other countries and regions, and of implanting backdoors in equipment and software and using American global technology brands to monitor and steal data).\nCollective Attribution in Cyberspace\nVol. 103\ninforce efforts to deter States from violating the List of Non-Binding Norms through “official attribution,” “collective attribution,” a “naming and shaming” strategy, and through a “collective response” by jointly imposing sanctions against States accused of violating the List. Ultimately, no State has officially announced that it will join the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative, not even the closest ally of the United States, the United Kingdom, although it promptly endorsed the pillars of the U.S. strategy. The International Cyber Deterrence Initiative has not evolved into an effective international initiative, such as the Proliferation Security Initiative or the International Counter Ransomware Initiative discussed below. In fact, the United States never officially launched the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative, and senior U.S. officials have rarely referred to it.\nThe literature includes only one study that references the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative, focusing solely on the collective response rather than the credible collective attribution that is implicitly a prerequisite to any collective response. Within this study, the scholar examined the policy embraced by each State party in the FVEY in building offensive cyber capabilities. The findings reveal that the FVEY States, excluding New Zealand, align with the approach of responding firmly to irresponsible State behavior in cyberspace. Additionally, those States have developed the offensive cyber capabilities needed, among others, to uphold such a policy. The scholar concludes by suggesting that the FVEY and other like-minded allies enhance the credibility of their deterrent collective response\n. THE WHITE HOUSE, supra note 12.\n. Unsurprisingly, the anticipation that States beyond the closest allies of the United States would align with American or British attribution statements and impose various costs—political, economic, and otherwise—proved unfounded. It appears that the United States has relinquished both initiatives and, together with its partners in the FVEY, has remained focused on the collective attribution endeavor, as detailed in the following section.\nHowever, beyond the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative and Advancing Responsible State Behavior in Cyberspace, in October 2021 the United States established an international initiative to counter the threat of ransomware cyber operations, which the Biden Administration has recently defined as a threat to U.S. national security. Although this International Counter Ransomware Initiative deals exclusively with criminally motivated ransomware cyber operations, it remains relevant in the context of the present discussion of collective attribution by States. This is because its primary goal is to uphold multinational cooperation to counteract ransomware threats and bolster both resiliency and deterrence. To achieve this, the International Counter Ransomware Initiative strengthens cooperation by facilitating the sharing of information and professional expertise among the participating States and private sector companies. More crucially for the focus of this article is its collaborative effort to detect and identify hackers or hacker groups involved in ransomware attacks, whether independently\n. An international law enforcement task force led by the UK's National Crime Agency and the FBI and consisting of eleven International Counter Ransomware Initiative member States (United States, United Kingdom, France, Japan, Switzerland, Canada, Australia, Sweden, Netherlands, Finland, and Germany) successfully executed an international disruption campaign, taking control of the website and services (ransomware-as-a-service) of LockBit. This criminal hacking group is recognized as the world's most harmful cybercrime group. The outcomes of this operation included the seizure in three countries of LockBit's data exfiltration infrastructure by members of the task force. Two LockBit operatives were arrested in coordination with Europol. The U.S. Department of Justice unsealed indictments against two Russian citizens for conspiring to commit LockBit ransomware attacks. The Department of Justice also announced that two defendants responsible for using LockBit to execute ransomware attacks were in custody and would face trial in the United States. The lessons learned from this experience could prove valuable for the United States and the United Kingdom in addressing the pitfalls of the current collective attribution process and response. This could serve as a test case demonstrating how successful cooperation between International Counter Ransomware Initiative member States can be in fighting criminally motivated, as well as politically motivated, cybercrime. Thus, the Initiative, in particular, may serve as an appropriate pilot for exploring optional solutions to better tackle the challenges associated with collective attributions and responses. More importantly, such solutions would enhance State accountability and the effectiveness of attributions in changing State behavior in cyberspace.\n## B. Five Eyes' Key Role\nDespite being an intelligence alliance, the FVEY partners are not obligated to full transparency between their intelligence agencies. However, they do share intelligence at a level of confidentiality not extended to other allies. This alliance is the core of the collective attribution strategy, while the United States and the United Kingdom are its driving forces. They cooperate in investigating wide-scale cyber attacks by exchanging confidential information and mobilizing, separately or in conjunction, to assist victim\n. Both the United States and the United Kingdom are responsible for all collective attributions listed in the table presented above, except one (Case 10), to be discussed below. The FVEY's attribution announcements are made concurrently and in coordination. However, they rely on sharing classified information, not on the findings of an independent FVEY multinational investigative team or any other form of international investigative mechanism. Like the decision to officially attribute State responsibility itself, endorsing an official attribution made by another State is a political prerogative for each sovereign State, which may announce it as its own official attribution. Such attribution determinations rely on various cumulative considerations, including the accuracy and credibility of evidence shared with all partners. While Canada has, thus far, actively participated in all collective attributions initiated by the United States and the United Kingdom, Australia refrained in three instances (Cases 6, 7, 13) and New Zealand in four (Cases 6, 7, 11, 13). Neither New Zealand nor Australia publicly justified their decision to refrain in each of these instances.\n## ii. EU and NATO Attributions or Partial Attribution Statements\nThe EU, representing twenty-seven European States, has had a notable practice of declarations in support of collective attributions. Thus far, it participated in eleven out of fourteen collective attributions, while NATO participated in six out of these same eleven attributions. However, the attribution statements on behalf of the EU and NATO could hardly be considered fully attributive. Instead, they may be perceived as a partial attribution of responsibility, making a limited contribution to the collective attribution strategy.\n. See, e.g., Cases 5, 13, supra Section IV(B) (providing examples in which the United Kingdom assisted the Georgian authorities in contending with and investigating the malicious cyber campaign); see Press Release, U.S. Embassy Tirana, Committed Partners in Cyberspace: U.S. Concludes First Defensive Hunt Operation in Albania (Mar. 23, 2023), https://al.usembassy.gov/committed-partners-in-cyberspace-u-s-concludes-first-defensive-hunt-operation-in-albania/.\n. At times, the dates on statements from Australia and New Zealand may not match those of other FVEY partners. However, the announcements are most likely published simultaneously with those of the FVEY partners, and at times the incompatibility of dates may be due to the different time zones.\nInternational Law Studies\n\n(a) The EU and NATO do not possess independent cyber investigative capabilities. Both rely heavily on more capable allies, namely the United States and the United Kingdom. Furthermore, EU and NATO member States, like Sweden, the Netherlands, Estonia, Austria, France, and Germany, each of which possess independent investigative capabilities, allegedly provide the EU security authorities with “deficient and incomplete” evidence in order to preserve the confidentiality of their cyber capabilities. To date, the EU has joined an official attribution initiated by one of its members only once (Case 10), and the attribution is highly questionable. NATO has never joined an attribution that was not initiated by the United States or the United Kingdom. It is worth noting that both States also face challenges in implementing a high degree of transparency with the EU security authorities due to the sensitivity and confidentiality of their intelligence sources. Nevertheless, the direct involvement of the United States and the United Kingdom in investigating cyber attacks appears to be a differentiating factor, possibly explaining why both, along with Canada and New Zealand, refrained from participating in the EU and Germany collective attribution (Case 10), while Australia settled for expressing solidarity.\n(b) The EU and NATO have joined collective attributions through brief declarations or statements issued on behalf of both Councils. The wording of these official declarations or statements must be cautious and measured to achieve unanimity within a truly brief period. Typically, they condemn the cyber attack in question, express concerns about it, and show solidarity with the affected States. The EU and NATO choose to avoid any explicit attribution of responsibility to the CRINK States. At the same time, the United States and the United Kingdom explicitly attribute responsibility primarily to specific official agents or organs of any State within the\n. Incoherency and Lack of Standardization\nThe collective FVEY attributions reviewed indicated incoherency, a lack of standardization, and an absence of transparent criteria, primarily in selecting which cyber operations the United States or the United Kingdom would lead the FVEY to collectively attribute. Likewise, there is uncertainty about the criteria guiding the EU and NATO in determining which attributions to publicly support, all while navigating possible political storms.[136] Questions persist regarding the degree of certainty justifying an attribution in the first place and how to measure that degree.[137] Further considerations involve the timing and format of coordinated announcements, whether through verbal statements by senior government officials (such as heads of states, relevant ministers, and senior officials from the U.S. National Security Council and their counterparts in other States), or by written statements of an authorized governmental agency or ministry, or both in concert.\n134. At times, it settles for filing or unsealing indictments in absentia (e.g., Cases 4, 7) or for joining advisories (e.g., Case 6). Occasionally, the U.S. action of indicting and/or joining an advisory is in addition to an explicit official political announcement (e.g., Case 9). Conversely, the other \"Four Eyes\" always officially attribute responsibility through official announcements of senior officials, mostly by written statements of the relevant ministers.\nFurthermore, the inclusion of Case 10 as a collective attribution in the table is highly questionable. This marks the inaugural and sole instance where the EU independently initiated, on behalf of its member States, a statement, purported to collectively attribute responsibility.[138] It was primarily in response to Germany's official attribution and ostensibly at its request.[139] Ultimately, the declaration was more of an urgent general warning to Russia against interfering in European national democratic processes rather than a distinct attribution of responsibility for enduring wrongdoings.[140] However, to enable consensus among the twenty-seven EU member States, the statement's wording was softened and generalized, using \"some\" member States, instead of specifying the States, and \"associating\" the wrongdoing with them, instead of clearly \"attributing\" it to Russia.[141] Unsurprisingly, this declaration did not spur additional States to participate in this collective \"attribution,\" except Australia, which expressed its solidarity.[142] By stark contrast, the EU declaration in Case 14, which addresses the same threat of Russian interference in foreign States' democratic pro\n138. Doubtful Credibility\nThere are only a small number of official attributions and an even smaller number of collective attributions that do not rely primarily on the American attribution process. The credibility and legitimacy deficiencies of the American attribution process, as highlighted in the previous Part—such as ambiguous normativity, limited transparency, and reliance on potentially biased American investigative teams instead of impartial multinational teams—persist unresolved in collective attributions. These issues may deter States from participating in explicit attributions as opposed to partial attributions. The cases reviewed indicate that States' willingness to participate in collective attributions based on the outcome of another State's national attribution process is limited, even if this system belongs to a cyber power State such as the United States or the United Kingdom. Consequently, the deterrence and effectiveness of such attributions also remain low.\nCase 11 requires a closer look as it raises serious doubts about the credibility of both the American and British attribution processes, and whether their outcomes are credible and persuasive enough to encourage a growing number of States to participate in such collective attributions. In this case, the Ukrainian Government suspected Russia just because it was then the only State interested in destabilizing Ukraine. Just forty-eight hours later, the United States and the United Kingdom provided the fastest attribution determination each of these allies had ever announced. Shaping “Rules of the Road”\nAiming to bolster deterrence, the United States and the United Kingdom initiated the collective attribution process as a response to attacking States in cyberspace.[150] However, in the absence of normative clarity, attribution announcements refer to unacceptable and irresponsible State behavior, rather than specifying international rules or norms allegedly breached by the given cyber attack. Thus, the policy implemented usually involves delegitimization (\"naming and shaming\") and retorsions, lawful measures that can be imposed without the need for detailed legal justification. The objective is to shape \"rules of the road\" by specifying instances of unacceptable cyber activity on case-by-case bases and to develop State practice accordingly. This involves instilling among the entire community of nations the perspectives of collective attributors regarding which cyber operations may constitute irresponsible State behavior.[151] Such activities would be deemed irresponsible State behavior when conducted by official State agents or entities, as well as by hacking groups affiliated with these entities, operating under their instruction, direction, or control.[152] Although the List of Non-Binding Norms does not refer to economic or national security espionage, bilateral agreements and multinational commitments prohibit the theft of intellectual property (IP), trade secrets, and business information to gain competitive commercial advantages.[153] Such multinational commitments may be an additional source for shaping \"rules of the road\" in the commitments' context.\nThe cases reviewed can be categorized into subcategories representing types of irresponsible State behavior. Each subcategory has the potential to form specific prohibitions on certain types of conduct, akin to rules of the road. Below is a classification of the cases reviewed into four subcategories,\n150. For additional clarity, she also suggests defining types of disruptive State cyber activities in various vulnerable sectors, such as energy security, essential medical care, economic stability, and democratic processes. Identifying a type of such cyber activity and examining it in its relevant context would determine whether it disrupts or denies another State’s ability to exercise its sovereign power to freely decide and act. If so, it would constitute a clear violation of the non-intervention norm, rendering it an unlawful activity. Since the UK Attorney General proposed this approach, the United States and the United Kingdom have jointly undertaken only two additional collective attributions (Cases 13, 14). However, instead of attributing unlawful cyber activities to Iran and Russia, the UK Foreign Secretary characterized Iranian actions as “reckless” and “unacceptable” and Russian actions as “completely unacceptable.” This aligns with the established practice of the FVEY, as evidenced in the cases reviewed. Nevertheless, adopting and implementing the British Attorney General’s integrated legal and political approach within the collective attribution strategy could potentially confer a more binding aspect to norms, such as the prohibitions on intervention and use of force, sovereignty of States, due diligence, and the boundaries of permitted espionage. This might create incentives for States, mindful of their reputation as responsible and law-abiding entities, to adhere to these norms as interpreted and applied to cyberspace. Furthermore, enforcing them through collective attribution and responses would be more consistent and coherent, thus, more effective in shaping State practice and international law.\n. Id. Sanctions as a Collective Response\nAnother dimension of the legality of the attributed violation lies in the appropriate response. As mentioned earlier, both the FVEY and the EU confine their responses to retorsions, such as travel bans and asset freezing, undertaken against the entities and persons engaged in conducting the malicious cyber attacks in question. The expectation that a collective attribution would prompt retorsions from a high number of participating States, forming an effective collective deterrent response, has not materialized as of yet. Nevertheless, such a response has become a common practice of the United States and to a lesser extent, the EU and the FVEY.\nAt the level of the United States, sanctions are imposed with greater frequency against individuals and entities based on findings and charges detailed in joint advisories or unsealed indictments and law enforcement investigations. Despite the considerable number of sanctioned individuals and entities, many are government personnel and entities associated with the CRINK, and a significant number have also been indicted. While the ultimate goal of sanctions is not to punish but to bring about a positive change in behavior, this change has not materialized as of yet. At the level of the FVEY partners, the United Kingdom has regulated its own independent cyber related sanctions regime and occasionally imposed sanctions in coordination with the United States. Australia legislated a cyber sanctions law in December 2021. In January 2024, it implemented it for the first time against a Russian cybercriminal found responsible for the Medibank\n. Moreover, the EU's process of imposing sanctions in response to cyber attacks is too slow and less effective; it may extend even beyond a year, as the decision must be unanimous and rely on evidence that can withstand judicial scrutiny. Thus far, the EU has sanctioned, under its cyber-related sanctions framework, only eight individuals and four entities affiliated with the CRINK, encompassing both asset freezes and travel bans. These sanctions were instituted in two phases, in July and October of 2020. As of now, no additional sanctions have been imposed through this channel, and there have been no challenges to review any of these sanctions before the European Court of Justice. Therefore, it seems that the EU cyber-sanction regime may have “already run its course,” as anticipated by some critics. Furthermore, a German research team, which analyzed the EU's collective response in Cases 1–4, questioned the effectiveness of such responses, doubting whether they “really have a deterrent effect on aggressors or are ultimately just symbolic politics.”\nDespite the above, this article does not purport to reach an unequivocal conclusion, based on sufficient credible information, regarding the effectiveness of the collective attribution and sanctions policy in achieving its primary objectives. Ultimately, sanctions are not designed to punish but rather to motivate positive changes in State behavior. Given that the main outlaw States in cyberspace—Russia, Iran, and North Korea—are already subject to extensive multinational sanctions regimes for reasons unrelated to “irresponsible” malicious cyber operations, the impact of sanctions imposed as a response to malicious cyber activities is difficult to evaluate decisively. Nevertheless, the increasing frequency and scale of politically motivated cyber operations suggest that the deterring effect of collective attributions, along with retorsions, is weak. Due to the lack of authorized information regarding the outcomes of these sanctions and in the face of persistent politically motivated cyber attacks originating from the same culpable States and orchestrated by their governmental entities, it would not be inaccurate to argue that the effectiveness of this policy has yet to be conclusively demonstrated. Meanwhile, it still has a symbolic, declarative impact needed to emphasize the red lines that States should not cross.\nIn conclusion, at present, collective attribution is no more than the upshot of the national attribution process, mostly American and British, with the addition of evidence sharing with like-minded States, in a manner that imposes no burden on the U.S. or UK intelligence community. The United States and the United Kingdom are always the driving force, while a CRINK State almost always stands on the receiving end. States and alliances participating in collective attributions, particularly the EU and FVEY, do not determine whether to join the attribution through direct involvement in investigative and attribution processes, but rather are influenced by political affiliations and international commitments within international frameworks, such as the G7, G20, and U.S.-EU or UK-EU dialogues. As a result, the collectiveness as implemented in the attribution process does not bolster the credibility of the American or British attribution determinations. This could notably change if the number of States committed to joining the attributions significantly increases, not due to political pressure or other political considerations, but rather due to an enhanced, joint, impartial, transparent, professional, and multinational process as the International Cyber Ransomware Initiative has recently demonstrated within its limited\n. CONCLUSION\nMore than a decade has passed since Leon Panetta first used the metaphor of the Pearl Harbor attack to depict how serious and risky a cyber attack could be, warning “potential aggressors . . . that the United States has the capacity to locate them and to hold them accountable for their actions.” $^{174}$ Even graver and more precise warnings have been issued recurringly by U.S. presidents and senior officials in administrations since 2012. $^{175}$ President Biden, who during his first weeks in office had to handle a series of serious ransomware cyber operations originating in Russia that dealt a blow to U.S. public interests, announced: “I made it clear to President Putin . . . that the days of the United States rolling over in the face of Russia’s aggressive actions—interfering with our elections . . .—are over. We will not hesitate to raise the cost on Russia . . .” $^{176}$ In the same speech, the President emphasized that only nations “working together and in common” can solve “the accelerating global challenges.” He added, “we [the United States] cannot do it alone.” That is easier said than done in the international arena. Despite technological developments that have improved attribution capabilities, the international community has not yet established a binding legal framework for cyberspace. Instead, the United States, along with the United Kingdom, has chosen to build upon a national official attribution system by imposing collective attribution and responses to the wrongdoing, aiming to concurrently achieve two goals: (1) to reinforce State deterrence through public collective attribution and imposing costs; and (2) shaping and internalizing “rules of the road” for responsible State behavior in cyberspace. $^{177}$\n173. See supra Section IV(A); supra note 122.\n174. Panetta, supra note 1.\n175. The White House, Remarks by President Biden on America's Place in the World (Feb. 4, 2021), https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/speeches-remarks/2021/02/04/remarks-by-president-biden-on-americas-place-in-the-world/.\n176. Id.\n177. See, e.g., The White House, Fact Sheet: Imposing Costs for Harmful Foreign Activities by the Russian Government (Apr. 15, 2021), https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/04/15/fact-sheet-imposing-costs-for-harmful-foreign-activities-by-the-Russian-government/ (the new executive order is designed to send a\nCollective Attribution in Cyberspace\nVol. 103\nHowever, this article highlights fundamental flaws that impact the credibility and legitimacy of this attribution process and subsequently its effectiveness. The United States, as the major attributor, assigns responsibility to specific States without allowing transparency regarding the evidence, the criteria of selecting the cases, and maintaining ambiguity about the legal grounds on which their charges rely. Furthermore, since the attribution determination in any given case is not subject to external and objective scrutiny, it is hard to indicate impartiality, legality, coherency, and consistency in the process, which collapses into one measure—attribution, accusation, judging, and punishing by retorsions. This is a far cry from satisfying any \"right\" or \"fair process.\" Thus far, the overwhelming majority of collective attributions have been American-led. The participants are American governmental experts, in cooperation mostly with American tech platforms whose loyalty to American national security interests is not questioned. There is no effort to involve independent, reputable international experts in the process, which is not sufficiently transparent and, on the face of things, may be perceived as one-sided. At most, the American process may constitute an exchange of views and intelligence sharing with counterpart agencies in the FVEY.\nClose and clandestine cooperation—among the FVEY—and sharing information with the EU's relevant institutions, as well as with a few like-minded States, is not enough to replace a proper procedure that would lend credibility and legitimacy to the process and its outcomes. The absence of representative, impartial multinational experts in the process exacerbates the legitimacy gap. This is even more true when the State at the receiving end of the attribution process is always a rival State from the CRINK group. Such dynamics erode the process' legitimacy and may discourage States from embracing its findings and joining the collective attributions, let alone responses. Moreover, it can explain the ineffectiveness of international initiatives, such as the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative and Advancing Responsible State Behavior in Cyberspace, and the negligible effectiveness of the collective attributions. This article pointed to one initiative, the International Counter Ransomware Initiative, which, in my opinion, has the potential to become more effective in countering ransomware and cooperating in law enforcement once the ransomware is detected or when credible intelligence can anticipate the details of the upcom\nsignal to Russia without any reference to specific international rules about the cost Russia might pay if it continues with its destabilizing actions).\n\nThis article presents the considerable cumulative experience gained from destructive and disruptive State or State-sponsored cyber attacks and their accompanying attribution processes. This, coupled with the growing number of States expressing their perspectives in enduring public debates regarding the terms and boundaries for applying major international norms to cyberspace,[179] illustrate the image of a wide-open field that must be fenced in by further development and regulation. In my opinion, there is fertile ground for a justified reevaluation of the collective attribution process and the responses to cyber wrongdoing. This is critical to bolster the credibility, legitimacy, and subsequently the effectiveness of these collective attributions in shaping the rules of road and enhancing State accountability.\n178. WannaCry (May 2017)\nA ransomware cyber operation in which hundreds of thousands of computers were hacked and encrypted in over 150 States, causing serious economic damage and disrupting vital public services like healthcare, transportation, banks, etc.\nOn December 19, 2017, the United States and the United Kingdom led the FVEY members to attribute this cyber attack to North Korea, simultaneously and in coordination, constituting the first collective attribution.         "12": "THE WHITE HOUSE, NATIONAL CYBER STRATEGY OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA 21 (2018); see also Jeremy Hunt, UK Foreign Sec’y, Deterrence in the Cyber Age Speech at Glasgow University (Mar. 7, 2019), https://www.gov.uk/government/speech International Law Studies 2024 This article aims to evaluate the collective attribution policy and process implementation—primarily by the United States and its close allies—and its effectiveness over the years through mapping and examining all the collective attribution determinations announced from the first one (WannaCry) through January 1, 2024. For the purposes of this article, “official attribution” refers to any public, verbal or non-verbal, statement made by a senior official of a State authorized to formally attribute responsibility for a given cyber attack to another State. Heads of State, ministries of foreign affairs, and other ministries whose mandate includes cybersecurity naturally hold such authority. As such, official attributions must be both public and political. Therefore, in this research, indictments filed or unsealed by the U.S. Department of Justice, personal sanctions imposed by the U.S. Department of Treasury, advisory alerts issued by the U.S. Cybersecurity &amp; Infrastructure Security Agency, and other reports from national law enforcement agencies, cannot on their own constitute an official attribution of responsibility to a State. However, they can certainly provide grounds for the United States and other States to attribute responsibility officially and explicitly to another State. Subsequently, the term “collective attribution” refers to a State’s official attribution joined by at least one other nation’s official attribution. Alternately, it shall apply if the State’s official attribution announcement is accompanied simultaneously and in coordination with another State officially announcing a response to the same cyber operation through indictments, sanctions, or joint advisories. This article evaluates whether the collective attribution process and its outcomes can be perceived as legitimate and credible by the international community, including impartial, nonaligned States. Furthermore, it evaluates whether this process has become a crucial component in effectively holding States accountable for violating the List of Non-Binding Norms and in deterring States from such violations. Analyzing these and related issues requires a sound understanding of the official attribution process in practice, focusing on identifying legitimacy and credibility disparities, and researching the collective attributions announced so far. The article is built exclusively upon open-source intelligence. The article continues as follows. Part II describes the official attribution process, differentiating between technological, legal, and political attributions and discussing the reluctance of States to officially attribute re es/deterrence-in-the-cyber-age-speech-by-the-foreign-secretary (presenting the United Kingdom’s deterrence strategy, mirroring the U.S. approach). 274 Collective Attribution in Cyberspace Vol. 103 sponsibility. Part III explores major aspects of the American attribution process, the most influential one, excluding the internal division of labor among the U.S. national security and law enforcement entities. It includes five sections that characterize the American attribution process, each of which could affect the extent to which the process's outcomes would be perceived as credible and legitimate. The first is the instrumental ambiguity the United States has embraced in the absence of a binding international convention, which has an adverse effect on transparency and source-based legitimacy. The subsequent three sections—intelligence-based attribution, attribution by indictment, and the private sector's role in ensuring cyber security—are important for mitigating the challenge of transparency but are still insufficient to ensure credibility and legitimacy. The fifth section explores collaboration between the private sector, particularly American corporations, including the most powerful tech platforms globally, and U.S. national security entities responsible for the American attribution process. This all-American collaboration may raise serious concerns among non-American constituencies about the credibility and legitimacy of the U.S. attribution process and its outcomes. Part IV delves into the specific collective attributions starting with three international initiatives. Two of these, initially planned to catalyze and empower collective attributions, have already faded, while the third initiative holds potential as part of a solution. Section IV(B) is a table that succinctly presents fourteen cases of collective attribution, spanning from the first collective attribution on December 19, 2017, until January 1, 2024. A detailed overview of these fourteen cases appears as an annex at the end of this article. Section IV(C) analyzes the findings. Part V concludes. ## II. An Instrumental Ambiguity Cyberspace's unique technological attributes produce opportunities for cyber power States to surreptitiously generate significant strategic gains through covert cyber operations, thereby minimizing the risk of being held accountable for breaching the law and harming their reputation as law abiding States. On the one hand, States strive to evade legal responsibility by distancing themselves from any factual or legal linkage to the malicious cyber operations in question. On the other hand, national security interests dictate the non-disclosure of classified information for both victim and attacking States. However, such data could help them substantiate arguments to strengthen or dismiss relevant accusations. As mentioned above, States, particularly the leading powers involved in the Great Power Competition, have embraced instrumental ambiguity, including maintaining silence on questions related to the interpretation and application of recognized principles and rules of customary international law in cyberspace. The primary motive behind this policy is to retain a sufficient margin of maneuver to enable the protection and promotion of strategic national interests in the rapidly evolving cybersphere. This policy of ambiguity inherently leads to accountability gaps that the most influential cyber power States, like the United States, are reluctant to resolve. Nevertheless, it is crucial for these States to play a decisive role in shaping international cyber law in a manner and at a time that aligns best with their national security interests. Unsurprisingly, they seek to avoid situations requiring an independent, international, judicial forum, such as the International Court of Justice, to resolve legal ambiguities surrounding State conduct in cyberspace. Notwithstanding the growing number of States that have clarified, albeit partially and cautiously, their views about a limited number of legal questions, the policy of ambiguity still prevails. The policy influences policymakers when considering whether to officially attribute responsibility and Collective Attribution in Cyberspace Vol. 103 when considering how transparent to be regarding relevant evidence and legal arguments.³⁹ Official attribution regarding cyber incidents in itself does not eliminate the need for transparency. This requirement is inherent in the legal obligation to substantiate State responsibility in both non-cyber and cyber incidents.⁴⁰ Transparency is essential to legitimize the official attribution by reflecting its “right process” through its process-based and outcome-based legitimacy.⁴¹ In the absence of accessible international judicial or quasi-judicial forums, as well as an impartial international monitoring institution, conflicting States might seek to influence the final “judgment” of the “international court of legitimacy.” This type of influence often involves legitimizing one side while delegitimizing the other. To achieve this, States should enhance transparency regarding their findings and, more importantly, with respect to processes and procedures undertaken. This includes ensuring that they align with Thomas Franck’s concept of the “right process.”⁴² The degree to which this transparency is genuine and comprehensive serves to strengthen their arguments in attributing responsibility or denying it, respectively. Relying solely on the investigative role of the United States or the United Kingdom, coupled with limited transparency and unwillingness to disclose persuasive evidence, opens the door to plausible deniability. Excluding independent, objective, and multinational experts, as well as representatives from other States, from participating in the attribution process also provides grounds for criticizing the integrity of the process. Nevertheless, the investigation team determining the attribution remains exclusively American. The limited number of participating States might also indicate that those States, which the United States and the United Kingdom interchangeably have not allowed to participate in the process or share classified information, are hesitant to blindly trust American or British intelligence assessments. Considering that the United States is the driving force behind these attributions and that its rivals, such as the CRINK States, are consistently on the receiving end underscores the importance of challenging the credibility of the process and its outcomes. Concurrently with intelligence-based attribution, the United States has endorsed, on its own, another method to mitigate the demand for transparency. This is attribution by indictment (\"naming and shaming\"). The next section will demonstrate that, despite its relative transparency, attribution by indictment has not proven a benchmark for credibility and trust. ## C. Attribution by Indictment Until now, the United States stands as the first and only State to “name and shame” by indicting, in absentia, foreign State-sponsored hackers, mostly citizens of the CRINK. They have been accused of breaching the U.S. Code by committing cybercrimes against Americans and U.S. entities. These indictments provide an opportunity to describe their worldwide malicious cyber activity. They include declassified information about unlawful cyber activities, shedding light on relevant State responsibility. This responsibility stems from the fact that, while committing the unlawful activities, the defendants were either State agents (such as soldiers, officers, or other government officials) or third parties under the State’s control, direction, instruction, or empowered by the law of that State to exercise elements of governmental authority.⁴⁸ However, indicting unlawful combatants, such as spies captured during peacetime or armed conflict while conducting their mission in the territory ⁴⁸. Articles on State Responsibility, supra note 20, arts. 4–5, 8. Collective Attribution in Cyberspace Vol. 103 of the accusing State, is unexceptional and reflects customary international law.⁴⁹ Nevertheless, indicting, in absentia, defendants identified as official agents of a foreign State for remotely hacking and damaging, during peacetime, targets located in the territory of the accusing State is both exceptional and unprecedented.⁵⁰ This could be acceptable if the hacks were criminally motivated and could not be attributed to a specific State, according to the Articles on State Responsibility. The U.S. Attorney General, William Barr, admitted that “traditional military and intelligence activity is a separate sphere of conduct that ought not be subject to domestic criminal law,” with the recognized exception noted above of charging intelligence officers operating undercover in the United States.⁵¹ Barr introduced new and unprecedented exceptions such as State-sponsored computer intrusions “for the purpose of intellectual property theft for the use of [the Chinese] private sector, bank robbery, and interfering with our democratic elections” and “deliberate, indiscriminate theft of vast amounts of sensitive personal data of civilians,”⁵² as occurred in the case of hacking Equifax. In Barr’s words, such cases “cannot be countenanced.”⁵³ In fact, such cases have led to the submission of indictments in deviation from the customary principles of international law and the recognized principle of criminal responsibility. One scholar labeled this a “judicialized attribution,” a new tool to convey more concrete and less political attribution focusing on the evidence and lawfulness of the behavior according to domestic law rather than international law.⁵⁴ This is despite the fact that both the superiors and subordinates who followed their orders purportedly committed the attributed crimes remotely from",

However, the jury operates behind closed doors, hearing the federal prosecutor and live testimonies of relevant witnesses, mostly federal investigators, and American cyber security and technology experts. In fact, the process is controlled and guided by the federal prosecutor of the case rather than a judge. Moreover, the indictments may also rely on evidence from American tech and cybersecurity companies, which, as explored below, closely collaborate with local governmental authorities. The national loyalty of these companies is often taken for granted.55 While this perception may not be entirely accurate, it is sufficient to undermine the trust in the impartiality and credibility of the American attribution process by significant portions of the international community, particularly populations and governments in the Global South. As mentioned above, a growing number of States have publicly endorsed the view that States attributing responsibility do not need to disclose classified evidence. The next section delves into the significant role played by the private sector, particularly in the United States, illustrating how private sector collaboration with the U.S. Government may enhance the level of transparency in determining and announcing official attributions. However, concurrently, it may raise concerns about the legitimacy and credibility of such attributions. ## D. The Role of the Private Sector The private sector, through its major tech and cyber security firms, plays a key role in the attribution process, as it possesses significant tech capabilities for detecting and investigating cyber incidents. Western companies, mostly American, such as Meta (Facebook, WhatsApp, Messenger, Instagram), Microsoft (Windows, Azure), Amazon (Amazon Web Services), Alphabet (Google, YouTube), X (previously Twitter), Apple, Hewlett Packard, and Verizon, dominate cyberspace in both software and hardware, encompassing global social media, big data, cloud services, artificial intelligence, computer operating systems, and search engines. Each of these realms is a playground where any vulnerability exposed by third parties could be exploited, posing serious threats to the company's reputation and business success. Thus, these companies invest vast resources to consistently lead in technology, developing cutting-edge capabilities to detect, investigate, and thwart any threat, regardless of its motives through in-house cyber threat intelligence teams. Moreover, global tech platforms, in particular, have achieved worldwide dominance and maintain a formidable presence in cyberspace, a level of control that State cyber powers, including a cyber superpower like the United States, struggle to maintain.⁶⁷ Additional- ⁶⁶. Nevertheless, voices are growing, as embodied in proposals and decisions, calling to limit the global impact of Collective Attribution in Cyberspace Vol. 103 ly, civil society organizations, such as the Citizen Lab, which focus mostly on safeguarding human rights from malicious cyber operations, and leading multinational cyber security firms, such as Mandiant, CrowdStrike, Kaspersky, and Symantec, have been evolving their cyber security expertise to successfully detect, thwart, and investigate any harmful cyber operation from any source.⁶⁸ That said, victim States less capable in cyberspace would seek immediate assistance from a cyber power ally to confront any hostile cyber operation or campaign and investigate accountability. Typically, such aid would involve collaboration with domestic or global cyber security and tech companies that have become major players in the field of cyber threat intelligence, holding capabilities that may even exceed those of government intelligence agencies.⁶⁹ These capabilities are crucial for gathering, processing, and analyzing technological findings to promptly establish situational awareness for the State's decision-makers.⁷⁰ Multiple firms have already engaged in such activities and provided their client States, and sometimes the public, with relatively prompt and detailed technical reports. These reports may include clear-cut technical evidence to detect and distinctly identify the perpetrators. However, technical attribution alone is not always sufficient for attributing responsibility with a full or high level of certainty. Unless biased (as discussed in the following section), they tend to classify the hostile cyber operation as sophisticated, suggesting potential execution by either an anonymous cyber power State or hackers sponsored by such a State.72 Technical attributions are usually faster, more detailed, and more transparent than official attributions, which are, to a greater extent restricted by confidentiality and related considerations of national security. This course of action characterizes private sector companies and has a double motivation, rooted both in business interests (business-based) and adherence to norms (norms-based). Naturally, the firms that are driven by business motives are interested in branding themselves—domestically and internationally—as the leading and most reliable professional actors in their fields, ahead of any existing or potential competitor. Such branding should go hand in hand with positioning the firms as prioritizing and aligning with values of universal human rights and other major norms included in the List of Non-Binding Norms, which reflect responsible peacetime State behavior in cyberspace. In this context, national and international responsibility to secure human life and well-being in an unregulated and risky cyberspace, at least by sharing relevant information with the public, has become a matter of utmost importance. Occasionally, a private sector technological investigation may lead to complete attribution, including identification of the culprit State or its official organ.73 This occurs despite the general business orientation to avoid involvement in inter-State conflicts. In such circumstances, the company's explicit technological attribution may influence international public opinion, delegitimizing the suspected State in the eyes of other States. Furthermore, any State could become a victim of similar unacceptable behavior at any time, and each may use such attributions to politically attribute responsibility to the suspected State. The following section addresses the collaboration U.S. national security agencies maintain with relevant American private sector companies, including in the context of the attribution process. Naturally, this partnership is not completely transparent, nor is it exclusive to the United States. It also encompasses attribution determinations, raising doubts about the extent to which these determinations should be perceived as credible and legitimate through the lens of neutral observers. ## E. Private Sector Collaboration with Governments A voluntary contribution by private sector companies to national efforts to defend the country from external threats is common, self-evident, and not limited to wartime. Thus, authorities of States cooperate and maintain close and confidential ties with leading domestic entities in the private sector in every relevant field, including health, transportation, tech-industry, telecommunications, and cybersecurity. Liberal democracies, as opposed to authoritarian regimes, maintain such cooperation within the boundaries of law. The Snowden disclosures of June 2013 about secret National Security Agency (NSA) operations involving American telecom companies rein",

However, in the absence of an independent international mechanism of accountability, the American attribution process, including the said collaboration, should withstand the scrutiny of its primary target constituency—the international community or international public opinion. Similarly, transparency may partially manifest itself in three dimensions: unexpected and undesired transparency—by leakers and whistleblowers; forced and balanced transparency—exclusively by virtue of judicial warrants that balance between conflicted interests, usually national security on one side and human rights on the other; and coordinated transparency—at the initiative of federal authorities in concert with the respective tech platforms. ⁸³. The next Part focuses on the collective attribution policy that the United States, along with its closest allies, has been implementing since 2017. Given the experience to date, should this policy be welcomed or re-evaluated? That is the question discussed below. ## IV. COLLECTIVE ATTRIBUTION In 2017, in the wake of two developments—the collapse of the fifth round of the UN–GGE and large-scale cyber attacks such as WannaCry and NotPetya—the United States and the United Kingdom extended the policy of official attribution to a new pattern of collective attribution aimed at deterring States from violating norms of responsible State behavior in cyberspace. As the table below shows, all the reviewed collective attributions, except one, relied on the national attribution processes of the United States and the United Kingdom regarding cyber attacks that targeted them or their allies. Prior to discussing the cumulative experience of the collective attribution concept per se, and to illustrate the complete picture in this context, the first section of this Part reviews three international initiatives that the United States introduced to deter States and advance responsible peacetime State behavior in cyberspace in conjunction with holding States accountable by relying on the concept of collective attribution. ## A. Collective Attribution Within International Initiatives Despite the legal obstacles and instrumental ambiguity noted above, the List of Non-Binding Norms remains the main international instrument to hold States accountable for wrongdoing that violates the voluntary norms of responsible peacetime State behavior in cyberspace. This accountability is essential for establishing effective deterrence, while the attribution determination is a keystone for invoking accountability in any given incident. In its updated National Cyber Strategy, the Trump Administration announced the launch of the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative to re 2023), https://www.theregister.com/2023/09/20/huawei_china_claims/ (reporting on post of China’s Ministry of State Security on WeChat, in which the United States is accused of running cyber attacks and espionage for more than ten years against China, Russia, and forty-five other countries and regions, and of implanting backdoors in equipment and software and using American global technology brands to monitor and steal data). Collective Attribution in Cyberspace Vol. 103 inforce efforts to deter States from violating the List of Non-Binding Norms through “official attribution,” “collective attribution,” a “naming and shaming” strategy, and through a “collective response” by jointly imposing sanctions against States accused of violating the List.¹⁰⁹ Ultimately, no State has officially announced that it will join the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative, not even the closest ally of the United States, the United Kingdom, although it promptly endorsed the pillars of the U.S. strategy.¹¹⁰ The International Cyber Deterrence Initiative has not evolved into an effective international initiative, such as the Proliferation Security Initiative¹¹¹ or the International Counter Ransomware Initiative discussed below. In fact, the United States never officially launched the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative, and senior U.S. officials have rarely referred to it.¹¹² The literature includes only one study that references the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative, focusing solely on the collective response rather than the credible collective attribution that is implicitly a prerequisite to any collective response.¹¹³ Within this study, the scholar examined the policy embraced by each State party in the FVEY in building offensive cyber capabilities. The findings reveal that the FVEY States, excluding New Zealand, align with the approach of responding firmly to irresponsible State behavior in cyberspace. Additionally, those States have developed the offensive cyber capabilities needed, among others, to uphold such a policy. In September 2019, the United States, Australia, and the Netherlands co-sponsored a new international initiative and, together with twenty-five other States, issued a Joint Statement on Advancing Responsible State Behavior in Cyberspace.[114] This statement includes a commitment to hold States accountable, that is, to collectively attribute State responsibility for violating the List of Non-Binding Norms. It also calls on States to transparently impose costs under international law. The Advancing Responsible State Behavior in Cyberspace has only been invoked once since 2019. On February 21, 2020, fifteen out of the twenty-eight Advancing Responsible State Behavior in Cyberspace partner States teamed up with Georgia and attributed responsibility to Russia for a disruptive cyber campaign conducted by the GRU. Collective Attribution in Cyberspace Vol. 103 Cronos.¹²² An international law enforcement task force led by the UK's National Crime Agency and the FBI and consisting of eleven International Counter Ransomware Initiative member States (United States, United Kingdom, France, Japan, Switzerland, Canada, Australia, Sweden, Netherlands, Finland, and Germany) successfully executed an international disruption campaign, taking control of the website and services (ransomware-as-a-service) of LockBit. This criminal hacking group is recognized as the world's most harmful cybercrime group. The outcomes of this operation included the seizure in three countries of LockBit's data exfiltration infrastructure by members of the task force. Two LockBit operatives were arrested in coordination with Europol. The U.S. Department of Justice unsealed indictments against two Russian citizens for conspiring to commit LockBit ransomware attacks. The Department of Justice also announced that two defendants responsible for using LockBit to execute ransomware attacks were in custody and would face trial in the United States. The lessons learned from this experience could prove valuable for the United States and the United Kingdom in addressing the pitfalls of the current collective attribution process and response. This could serve as a test case demonstrating how successful cooperation between International Counter Ransomware Initiative member States can be in fighting criminally motivated, as well as politically motivated, cybercrime. Thus, the Initiative, in particular, may serve as an appropriate pilot for exploring optional solutions to better tackle the challenges associated with collective attributions and responses. More importantly, such solutions would enhance State accountability and the effectiveness of attributions in changing State behavior in cyberspace. ## B. This alliance is the core of the collective attribution strategy, while the United States and the United Kingdom are its driving forces. The FVEY's attribution announcements are made concurrently and in coordination.¹²⁸ However, they rely on sharing classified information, not on the findings of an independent FVEY multinational investigative team or any other form of international investigative mechanism. Like the decision to officially attribute State responsibility itself, endorsing an official attribution made by another State is a political prerogative for each sovereign State, which may announce it as its own official attribution. Such attribution determinations rely on various cumulative considerations, including the accuracy and credibility of evidence shared with all partners. While Canada has, thus far, actively participated in all collective attributions initiated by the United States and the United Kingdom, Australia refrained in three instances (Cases 6, 7, 13) and New Zealand in four (Cases 6, 7, 11, 13). Neither New Zealand nor Australia publicly justified their decision to refrain in each of these instances. ## ii. EU and NATO Attributions or Partial Attribution Statements The EU, representing twenty-seven European States, has had a notable practice of declarations in support of collective attributions. Thus far, it participated in eleven out of fourteen collective attributions, while NATO participated in six out of these same eleven attributions. However, the attribution statements on behalf of the EU and NATO could hardly be considered fully attributive. Instead, they may be perceived as a partial attribution of responsibility, making a limited contribution to the collective attribution strategy. ¹²⁷. See, e.g., Cases 5, 13, supra Section IV(B) (providing examples in which the United Kingdom assisted the Georgian authorities in contending with and investigating the malicious cyber campaign); see Press Release, U.S. Embassy Tirana, Committed Partners in Cyberspace: U.S. Concludes First Defensive Hunt Operation in Albania (Mar. 23, 2023), https://al.usembassy.gov/committed-partners-in-cyberspace-u-s-concludes-first-defensive-hunt-operation-in-albania/. ¹²⁸. At times, the dates on statements from Australia and New Zealand may not match those of other FVEY partners. However, the announcements are most likely published simultaneously with those of the FVEY partners, and at times the incompatibility of dates may be due to the different time zones. International Law Studies 2024 The following are some probable causes driving this partial level of EU and NATO participation in collective attributions: (a) The EU and NATO do not possess independent cyber investigative capabilities. Both rely heavily on more capable allies, namely the United States and the United Kingdom. Furthermore, EU and NATO member States, like Sweden, the Netherlands, Estonia, Austria, France, and Germany, each of which possess independent investigative capabilities, allegedly provide the EU security authorities with “deficient and incomplete” evidence in order to preserve the confidentiality of their cyber capabilities.¹²⁹ To date, the EU has joined an official attribution initiated by one of its members only once (Case 10), and the attribution is highly questionable. NATO has never joined an attribution that was not initiated by the United States or the United Kingdom. It is worth noting that both States also face challenges in implementing a high degree of transparency with the EU security authorities due to the sensitivity and confidentiality of their intelligence sources. Nevertheless, the direct involvement of the United States and the United Kingdom in investigating cyber attacks appears to be a differentiating factor, possibly explaining why both, along with Canada and New Zealand, refrained from participating in the EU and Germany collective attribution (Case 10), while Australia settled for expressing solidarity.¹³⁰ (b) The EU and NATO have joined collective attributions through brief declarations or statements issued on behalf of both Councils. The wording of these official declarations or statements must be cautious and measured to achieve unanimity within a truly brief period. Typically, they condemn the cyber attack in question, express concerns about it, and show solidarity with the affected States. The EU and NATO choose to avoid any explicit attribution of responsibility to the CRINK States. Shaping “Rules of the Road” Aiming to bolster deterrence, the United States and the United Kingdom initiated the collective attribution process as a response to attacking States in cyberspace.[150] However, in the absence of normative clarity, attribution announcements refer to unacceptable and irresponsible State behavior, rather than specifying international rules or norms allegedly breached by the given cyber attack. Thus, the policy implemented usually involves delegitimization (\"naming and shaming\") and retorsions, lawful measures that can be imposed without the need for detailed legal justification. The objective is to shape \"rules of the road\" by specifying instances of unacceptable cyber activity on case-by-case bases and to develop State practice accordingly. This involves instilling among the entire community of nations the perspectives of collective attributors regarding which cyber operations may constitute irresponsible State behavior.[151] Such activities would be deemed irresponsible State behavior when conducted by official State agents or entities, as well as by hacking groups affiliated with these entities, operating under their instruction, direction, or control.[152] Although the List of Non-Binding Norms does not refer to economic or national security espionage, bilateral agreements and multinational commitments prohibit the theft of intellectual property (IP), trade secrets, and business information to gain competitive commercial advantages.[153] Such multinational commitments may be an additional source for shaping \"rules of the road\" in the commitments' context. The cases reviewed can be categorized into subcategories representing types of irresponsible State behavior. Each subcategory has the potential to form specific prohibitions on certain types of conduct, akin to rules of the road. Below is a classification of the cases reviewed into four subcategories,",

Collective Attribution in Cyberspace Vol. 103 ## 4. Sanctions as a Collective Response Another dimension of the legality of the attributed violation lies in the appropriate response. As mentioned earlier, both the FVEY and the EU confine their responses to retorsions, such as travel bans and asset freezing, undertaken against the entities and persons engaged in conducting the malicious cyber attacks in question. The expectation that a collective attribution would prompt retorsions from a high number of participating States, forming an effective collective deterrent response, has not materialized as of yet.¹⁶¹ Nevertheless, such a response has become a common practice of the United States and to a lesser extent, the EU and the FVEY. At the level of the United States, sanctions are imposed with greater frequency against individuals and entities based on findings and charges detailed in joint advisories or unsealed indictments and law enforcement investigations. Despite the considerable number of sanctioned individuals and entities, many are government personnel and entities associated with the CRINK, and a significant number have also been indicted.¹⁶² While the ultimate goal of sanctions is not to punish but to bring about a positive change in behavior,¹⁶³ this change has not materialized as of yet. At the level of the FVEY partners, the United Kingdom has regulated its own independent cyber related sanctions regime and occasionally imposed sanctions in coordination with the United States.¹⁶⁴ Australia legislated a cyber sanctions law in December 2021. On the other hand, the EU failed to bolster the deterrent impact of the collective attributions it opted to join (eleven out of fourteen cases) due to the cautious wording of its declarations, as described above—far from being an incisive attribution determination. Moreover, the EU's process of imposing sanctions in response to cyber attacks is too slow and less effective; it may extend even beyond a year, as the decision must be unanimous and rely on evidence that can withstand judicial scrutiny. Thus far, the EU has sanctioned, under its cyber-related sanctions framework, only eight individuals and four entities affiliated with the CRINK, encompassing both asset freezes and travel bans. These sanctions were instituted in two phases, in July and October of 2020. As of now, no additional sanctions have been imposed through this channel, and there have been no challenges to review any of these sanctions before the European Court of Justice.¹⁶⁶ Therefore, it seems that the EU cyber-sanction regime may have “already run its course,” as anticipated by some critics.¹⁶⁷ Furthermore, a German research team, which analyzed the EU's collective response in Cases 1–4, questioned the effectiveness of such responses, doubting whether they “really have a deterrent effect on aggressors or are ultimately just symbolic politics.”¹⁶⁸ Despite the above, this article does not purport to reach an unequivocal conclusion, based on sufficient credible information, regarding the effectiveness of the collective attribution and sanctions policy in achieving its primary objectives. Ultimately, sanctions are not designed to punish but rather to motivate positive changes in State behavior.¹⁷⁰ Given that the main outlaw States in cyberspace—Russia, Iran, and North Korea—are already subject to extensive multinational sanctions regimes for reasons unrelated to “irresponsible” malicious cyber operations,¹⁷¹ the impact of sanctions imposed as a response to malicious cyber activities is difficult to evaluate decisively. Nevertheless, the increasing frequency and scale of politically motivated cyber operations suggest that the deterring effect of collective attributions, along with retorsions, is weak.¹⁷² Due to the lack of authorized information regarding the outcomes of these sanctions and in the face of persistent politically motivated cyber attacks originating from the same culpable States and orchestrated by their governmental entities, it would not be inaccurate to argue that the effectiveness of this policy has yet to be conclusively demonstrated. Meanwhile, it still has a symbolic, declarative impact needed to emphasize the red lines that States should not cross. In conclusion, at present, collective attribution is no more than the upshot of the national attribution process, mostly American and British, with the addition of evidence sharing with like-minded States, in a manner that imposes no burden on the U.S. or UK intelligence community. The United States and the United Kingdom are always the driving force, while a CRINK State almost always stands on the receiving end. States and alliances participating in collective attributions, particularly the EU and FVEY, do not determine whether to join the attribution through direct involvement in investigative and attribution processes, but rather are influenced by political affiliations and international commitments within international frameworks, such as the G7, G20, and U.S.-EU or UK-EU dialogues. As a result, the collectiveness as implemented in the attribution process does not bolster the credibility of the American or British attribution determinations. CONCLUSION More than a decade has passed since Leon Panetta first used the metaphor of the Pearl Harbor attack to depict how serious and risky a cyber attack could be, warning “potential aggressors . . . that the United States has the capacity to locate them and to hold them accountable for their actions.” $^{174}$ Even graver and more precise warnings have been issued recurringly by U.S. presidents and senior officials in administrations since 2012. $^{175}$ President Biden, who during his first weeks in office had to handle a series of serious ransomware cyber operations originating in Russia that dealt a blow to U.S. public interests, announced: “I made it clear to President Putin . . . that the days of the United States rolling over in the face of Russia’s aggressive actions—interfering with our elections . . .—are over. We will not hesitate to raise the cost on Russia . . .” $^{176}$ In the same speech, the President emphasized that only nations “working together and in common” can solve “the accelerating global challenges.” He added, “we [the United States] cannot do it alone.” That is easier said than done in the international arena. Despite technological developments that have improved attribution capabilities, the international community has not yet established a binding legal framework for cyberspace. Instead, the United States, along with the United Kingdom, has chosen to build upon a national official attribution system by imposing collective attribution and responses to the wrongdoing, aiming to concurrently achieve two goals: (1) to reinforce State deterrence through public collective attribution and imposing costs; and (2) shaping and internalizing “rules of the road” for responsible State behavior in cyberspace. $^{177}$",

The United States, as the major attributor, assigns responsibility to specific States without allowing transparency regarding the evidence, the criteria of selecting the cases, and maintaining ambiguity about the legal grounds on which their charges rely. Furthermore, since the attribution determination in any given case is not subject to external and objective scrutiny, it is hard to indicate impartiality, legality, coherency, and consistency in the process, which collapses into one measure—attribution, accusation, judging, and punishing by retorsions. This is a far cry from satisfying any \"right\" or \"fair process.\" Thus far, the overwhelming majority of collective attributions have been American-led. The participants are American governmental experts, in cooperation mostly with American tech platforms whose loyalty to American national security interests is not questioned. There is no effort to involve independent, reputable international experts in the process, which is not sufficiently transparent and, on the face of things, may be perceived as one-sided. At most, the American process may constitute an exchange of views and intelligence sharing with counterpart agencies in the FVEY. Close and clandestine cooperation—among the FVEY—and sharing information with the EU's relevant institutions, as well as with a few like-minded States, is not enough to replace a proper procedure that would lend credibility and legitimacy to the process and its outcomes. The absence of representative, impartial multinational experts in the process exacerbates the legitimacy gap. This is even more true when the State at the receiving end of the attribution process is always a rival State from the CRINK group. Such dynamics erode the process' legitimacy and may discourage States from embracing its findings and joining the collective attributions, let alone responses. Moreover, it can explain the ineffectiveness of international initiatives, such as the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative and Advancing Responsible State Behavior in Cyberspace, and the negligible effectiveness of the collective attributions. This article pointed to one initiative, the International Counter Ransomware Initiative, which, in my opinion, has the potential to become more effective in countering ransomware and cooperating in law enforcement once the ransomware is detected or when credible intelligence can anticipate the details of the upcom signal to Russia without any reference to specific international rules about the cost Russia might pay if it continues with its destabilizing actions). 331 International Law Studies 2024 ing cyber attack. In my opinion, there is fertile ground for a justified reevaluation of the collective attribution process and the responses to cyber wrongdoing.
