The attribution determination is not necessarily contingent on legal proceedings. $^{18}$  The reasonableness of such an ex ante attribution must be assessed on a case-by-case basis and under no binding requirements of transparency and standard of proof. $^{19}$  Thus, it is no more than a public political denunciation, especially when not accompanied by legal claims and countermeasures. Although the attribution may rely on technical findings and additional evidence from any other source of information, it does not necessarily have to withstand the legal scrutiny that a formal legal attribution of State responsibility might face.\n\nAs noted above, the difficulties of legally attributing State responsibility will be addressed in a subsequent article. For the purposes of the present article, it is worth noting the following: pursuant to the rules of State responsibility, a State harmed by a malicious cyber operation that is willing to officially attribute responsibility to an attacking State and has a legal justification for a lawful response, must meet two cumulative requirements.[20] The first is to indicate a breach of an international rule that binds States under circumstances like those of the cyber incident in question. This might be controversial as long as international cyber law remains in its embryonic stage and the extent and conditions under which customary rules of international law would apply to cyberspace as binding law continue to be open-ended.     "International Law Studies\n\n2024\n\nAttorney General launched an investigation into that cyber attack.³⁴ Only in May 2020, in a speech she gave in the Bundestag, did Chancellor Merkel unprecedentedly, officially, and explicitly attribute to Russia responsibility for that cyber attack, adding that the attribution relies on “hard evidence” she personally saw.³⁵ No German official publicly explained the transformation from political, collective attribution in 2018 to an official and legal attribution made in 2020 by the Chancellor herself. One possible explanation might have been the relentless Russian attempts to meddle in the tense September 26, 2021, German elections and the urgent need to stop those attempts. The second, and so far, the last, exceptional official attribution reinforced this estimation. On September 5, 2021, Germany officially attributed to Russia responsibility for cyber attacks conducted by a cyber group dubbed Ghostwriter, even though the evidence was not “hard” but “reliable information” that established “suspicions” against the GRU.³⁶ This triggered an official diplomatic protest and an investigation, yet no one waited for its final findings due to the short time left (three weeks) until the elections.\n\nIt is noteworthy that this was the first report of a State officially holding another State accountable for a cyber attack and responding with an official diplomatic protest, relying on information that merely met the level of “suspicions.” Apparently, this sort of cutting corners or lowering the bar of evidence stemmed from the urgent need to stop or deter Russia from interfering with the quickly approaching German elections race. This coincides with the principle, according to which an official attribution is a purely political decision, not necessarily a legal attribution that should meet specific legal requirements. The attribution determination does not rely on full transparency or even a significant degree of transparency, let alone the ability to withstand any external, independent, and impartial scrutiny. This provides room for questioning the credibility and legitimacy of the official attribution. Part III addresses several segments of the U.S. national attribution process, examining how they may have potential positive or negative impacts on the legitimacy and credibility of the collective process and its outcomes.\n\n## III. EVALUATING ASPECTS OF LEGITIMACY AND CREDIBILITY IN THE ATTRIBUTION PROCESS\n\nNational security interests dictate confidentiality regarding classified intelligence, including information about sensitive cyber tools, detection capabilities, and military cyber capabilities. However, in the absence of multinational, impartial, legal, and professional scrutiny regarding the accuracy and lawfulness of the official attribution in any given situation, attributing States must be mindful of how various constituencies could perceive their attribution statements. Without accepted clear and binding rules, these statements may not be viewed as lawful. Nevertheless, there is a concerted effort to influence public opinion through enhancing the legitimacy of the attribution process. If successful, this could bolster the effectiveness of its attribution determinations.\n\nThe following sections address five segments that characterize the American attribution process, each of which could positively or negatively influence how the outcomes of the process are perceived for credibility and\n\n37. Except for attribution by indictment, these segments are relevant to the UK attribution process, as well as those of other like-minded cyber power States. Unlike authoritarian regimes, these States have embraced the courses of action described in the following sections to contend with the demand for transparency while striving to achieve the best result for their own national security interests.\n\n# A. An Instrumental Ambiguity\n\nCyberspace's unique technological attributes produce opportunities for cyber power States to surreptitiously generate significant strategic gains through covert cyber operations, thereby minimizing the risk of being held accountable for breaching the law and harming their reputation as law abiding States. On the one hand, States strive to evade legal responsibility by distancing themselves from any factual or legal linkage to the malicious cyber operations in question. On the other hand, national security interests dictate the non-disclosure of classified information for both victim and attacking States. However, such data could help them substantiate arguments to strengthen or dismiss relevant accusations.\n\nAs mentioned above, States, particularly the leading powers involved in the Great Power Competition, have embraced instrumental ambiguity, including maintaining silence on questions related to the interpretation and application of recognized principles and rules of customary international law in cyberspace. The primary motive behind this policy is to retain a sufficient margin of maneuver to enable the protection and promotion of strategic national interests in the rapidly evolving cybersphere. This policy of ambiguity inherently leads to accountability gaps that the most influential cyber power States, like the United States, are reluctant to resolve. Nevertheless, it is crucial for these States to play a decisive role in shaping international cyber law in a manner and at a time that aligns best with their national security interests. Unsurprisingly, they seek to avoid situations requiring an independent, international, judicial forum, such as the International Court of Justice, to resolve legal ambiguities surrounding State conduct in cyberspace.\n\nNotwithstanding the growing number of States that have clarified, albeit partially and cautiously, their views about a limited number of legal questions, the policy of ambiguity still prevails. The policy influences policymakers when considering whether to officially attribute responsibility and",
    "Collective Attribution in Cyberspace\n\nVol. 103\n\nwhen considering how transparent to be regarding relevant evidence and legal arguments.³⁹\n\nOfficial attribution regarding cyber incidents in itself does not eliminate the need for transparency. This requirement is inherent in the legal obligation to substantiate State responsibility in both non-cyber and cyber incidents.⁴⁰ Transparency is essential to legitimize the official attribution by reflecting its “right process” through its process-based and outcome-based legitimacy.⁴¹ In the absence of accessible international judicial or quasi-judicial forums, as well as an impartial international monitoring institution, conflicting States might seek to influence the final “judgment” of the “international court of legitimacy.” This type of influence often involves legitimizing one side while delegitimizing the other. To achieve this, States should enhance transparency regarding their findings and, more importantly, with respect to processes and procedures undertaken. This includes ensuring that they align with Thomas Franck’s concept of the “right process.”⁴² The degree to which this transparency is genuine and comprehensive serves to strengthen their arguments in attributing responsibility or denying it, respectively.\n\nRelying solely on the investigative role of the United States or the United Kingdom, coupled with limited transparency and unwillingness to disclose persuasive evidence, opens the door to plausible deniability. Excluding independent, objective, and multinational experts, as well as representatives from other States, from participating in the attribution process also provides grounds for criticizing the integrity of the process. These concerns are particularly significant given the common reality of blanket denials by accused States.\n\nShould a State that officially attributes State responsibility for wrongful acts in cyberspace evade disclosure of the evidence and confidential information upon which the attribution and, if undertaken, retribution rely?\n\nThe first to address this question, in November 2016, was Brian Egan, U.S. State Department Legal Advisor, who noted that States are not required to act with full transparency when attributing responsibility to another State.43 Since then, a growing number of States have embraced a legal stance that denies the obligation to reveal classified evidence prior to attribution or countermeasures, making the extent of disclosure a matter of policy that often involves complex considerations.44 Striking a balance between accountability, diplomatic relations, and, most importantly, national security, including the strategic interest of maintaining instrumental ambiguity, remains a significant challenge in the evolving landscape of cyberspace governance. Yet simply prioritizing national security interests to the extent of excluding transparency may erode trust in the attribution statement. Nevertheless, powers like the United States and the United Kingdom, which possess advanced cyber capabilities and robust intelligence, do not hesitate to base their attribution claims solely on their intelligence assessment system, thereby preserving confidentiality and national security interests.\n\n## B. Intelligence-Based Attribution\n\nThe term \"intelligence assessment\" usually does not imply absolute certainty nor admissibility in court but rather the degree of certainty and credibility with which a certain factual narrative should be perceived, using the qualifiers of the national intelligence community about high, moderate, or low likelihood/certainty of the narrative as described in the attribution statement.45 The degree of certainty obviously depends on the level of trust in the information collected and the extent to which it is considered reliable and credible. By endorsing this practice, both States have averted compromising sensitive intelligence to justify their official attribution and retorsion, which is a response within the prerogative of any State. Even if the attribution of State responsibility proves to be mistaken, the response undertaken remains lawful, albeit unfriendly, and is often reciprocally retaliated. Nevertheless, covert cyber operations remain a viable response, either alongside or instead of retorsions. However, if exposed, their legality would inevitably be challenged.\n\nCritics of intelligence assessment as major grounds for attribution argue that it relies on criteria that \"may at best amount to circumstantial evidence,\" far below the evidentiary standards used in courts.[46] This allows States to manipulate cases to fit preconceived narratives and embody political agendas; it may lead to misleading results involving the misinterpretation of information influenced by what later turns out to be a false conception.[47]\n\nNone of the official American attributions since 2014, nor any of the collective attributions that the United States and the United Kingdom have announced since 2017, have corroborated this criticism. Both States have officially attributed responsibility relying on their intelligence and a high degree of certainty (\"almost certainly\"). Some of these attributions have also referred to open-source investigative reports and technological findings of tech and cyber security companies, mostly American, as discussed below. Others were also followed, months or even years later, by detailed American indictments delivering the message that they rely on sufficient and admissible evidence. However, only a limited number of States have been sufficiently convinced or politically motivated to officially adopt and join these attribution statements. Attribution by Indictment\n\nUntil now, the United States stands as the first and only State to “name and shame” by indicting, in absentia, foreign State-sponsored hackers, mostly citizens of the CRINK. The Role of the Private Sector\n\nThe private sector, through its major tech and cyber security firms, plays a key role in the attribution process, as it possesses significant tech capabilities for detecting and investigating cyber incidents. Western companies, mostly American, such as Meta (Facebook, WhatsApp, Messenger, Instagram), Microsoft (Windows, Azure), Amazon (Amazon Web Services), Alphabet (Google, YouTube), X (previously Twitter), Apple, Hewlett Packard, and Verizon, dominate cyberspace in both software and hardware, encompassing global social media, big data, cloud services, artificial intelligence, computer operating systems, and search engines. Each of these realms is a playground where any vulnerability exposed by third parties could be exploited, posing serious threats to the company's reputation and business success. Thus, these companies invest vast resources to consistently lead in technology, developing cutting-edge capabilities to detect, investigate, and thwart any threat, regardless of its motives through in-house cyber threat intelligence teams. Moreover, global tech platforms, in particular, have achieved worldwide dominance and maintain a formidable presence in cyberspace, a level of control that State cyber powers, including a cyber superpower like the United States, struggle to maintain.⁶⁷ Additional-\n\n⁶⁶.     "International Law Studies\n\n2024\n\nnoted above, the decision whether to name the culprit State and officially attribute responsibility is purely political, and concerned vendor firms tend to comply with this.71 Experience thus far indicates that when tech and cyber security companies detect anomalies and even malicious cyber operations through their routine preventive and researching cyber security activities, rather than as a part of a service ordered by the victim State, they generally avoid involvement in what might be inter-State conflicts. Unless biased (as discussed in the following section), they tend to classify the hostile cyber operation as sophisticated, suggesting potential execution by either an anonymous cyber power State or hackers sponsored by such a State.72 Technical attributions are usually faster, more detailed, and more transparent than official attributions, which are, to a greater extent restricted by confidentiality and related considerations of national security. This course of action characterizes private sector companies and has a double motivation, rooted both in business interests (business-based) and adherence to norms (norms-based). Naturally, the firms that are driven by business motives are interested in branding themselves—domestically and internationally—as the leading and most reliable professional actors in their fields, ahead of any existing or potential competitor. Such branding should go hand in hand with positioning the firms as prioritizing and aligning with values of universal human rights and other major norms included in the List of Non-Binding Norms, which reflect responsible peacetime State behavior in cyberspace. In this context, national and international responsibility to secure human life and well-being in an unregulated and risky cyberspace, at least by sharing relevant information with the public, has become a matter of utmost importance.\n\nPrivate sector firms that investigate and expose malicious cyber tools and methodologies used in specific cyber attacks publish their findings to\n\n71.     "Collective Attribution in Cyberspace\n\nVol. 103\n\nraise awareness about these threats among both governmental and nongovernmental users. More importantly, this helps enhance their cyber security capabilities and their preparedness to detect and thwart such threats. At the same time, such information may raise suspicions that a specific cyber attack is, in fact, an act of State or a State-sponsored operation. Occasionally, a private sector technological investigation may lead to complete attribution, including identification of the culprit State or its official organ.73 This occurs despite the general business orientation to avoid involvement in inter-State conflicts. Such attribution is a proper alternative to the official attribution that the victim State may avoid due to its strategic and national security considerations, as noted above. In such circumstances, the company's explicit technological attribution may influence international public opinion, delegitimizing the suspected State in the eyes of other States. Furthermore, any State could become a victim of similar unacceptable behavior at any time, and each may use such attributions to politically attribute responsibility to the suspected State.\n\nThe following section addresses the collaboration U.S. national security agencies maintain with relevant American private sector companies, including in the context of the attribution process. Naturally, this partnership is not completely transparent, nor is it exclusive to the United States. It also encompasses attribution determinations, raising doubts about the extent to which these determinations should be perceived as credible and legitimate through the lens of neutral observers.\n\n## E. Private Sector Collaboration with Governments\n\nA voluntary contribution by private sector companies to national efforts to defend the country from external threats is common, self-evident, and not limited to wartime. Thus, authorities of States cooperate and maintain close and confidential ties with leading domestic entities in the private sector in every relevant field, including health, transportation, tech-industry, telecommunications, and cybersecurity. Liberal democracies, as opposed to authoritarian regimes, maintain such cooperation within the boundaries of law. The Snowden disclosures of June 2013 about secret National Security Agency (NSA) operations involving American telecom companies rein\n\n73. Mandiant, for instance, was the first to attribute APT1 to China in a detailed attribution report based on technical findings and other, not necessarily technical, information gathered by the firm. CrowdStrike was the first to attribute responsibility to Russia for the Democratic National Committee hack during the 2016 U.S. elections.",
    "International Law Studies\n\n2024\n\nforce the perception that companies in established democracies assist their governments \"even above and beyond their legal obligations to do so.\"74 Conversely, authoritarian regimes are guided primarily by their self-interest in ensuring the regime's security and sustainability and would, therefore, do whatever it takes to secure their regime. As the end justifies the means, not even universal human rights would pose a barrier. As a corollary, the private sector companies, including foreign multinational platform companies operating under such regimes, must comply with their orders and restrictive regulations.     "International Law Studies\n\nconflict, has become relevant to their operations.78 Moreover, they have come to maintain a formidable grip on major components, including social media, cloud services, software, computer infrastructure, and satellite internet services, to ensure connectivity even in difficult conditions, as has occurred during the war in Ukraine.79\n\nAlthough the myth that such powerful and global platforms are neutral pervades the tech industry, it does not align with reality, at least with respect to substantive issues, such as universal human rights, which the platforms favor over other regimes' interests.80 More significantly, in times of crisis, they may favor the victim side over the aggressor, as evidenced most recently during the war in Ukraine.81 Therefore, collaborating with the private sector—tech and cybersecurity companies and platforms—is crucial to successfully meet the challenge of ensuring cybersecurity, alongside resiliency, to overcome disruptive or destructive cyber operations in times of peace and war.82\n\n78.     "Collective Attribution in Cyberspace\n\nVol. 103\n\nScholars have already examined different facets of Private Sector-U.S. Government collaboration.⁸³ For the purposes of this article, it is important to focus on whether the collaboration of American multinational tech platforms with the American national security authorities undermines or, on the contrary, bolsters the credibility of the U.S. attribution process.⁸⁴ This is especially significant considering its key role in the collective attributions detailed in the following Part.\n\nUndoubtedly, such collaboration bolsters capabilities for revealing the truth behind any given cyber incident and establishing a solid attribution claim. However, in the absence of an independent international mechanism of accountability, the American attribution process, including the said collaboration, should withstand the scrutiny of its primary target constituency—the international community or international public opinion. Naturally, national security aspects of this collaboration remain confidential, though not always entirely so. Similarly, transparency may partially manifest itself in three dimensions: unexpected and undesired transparency—by leakers and whistleblowers; forced and balanced transparency—exclusively by virtue of judicial warrants that balance between conflicted interests, usually national security on one side and human rights on the other; and coordinated transparency—at the initiative of federal authorities in concert with the respective tech platforms.\n\n⁸³. Ashley Deeks, *Secrecy Surrogates*, 106 VIRGINIA LAW REVIEW 1395, 1430–42 (2020) (In light of the shift from a landscape of kinetic threats to that of cyber threats, Deeks suggests the technology companies, as another unsung secrecy surrogate, check and balance the executive branch’s secrecy to reduce abuse. The technology companies, including cybersecurity companies, cooperate with the executive branch’s relevant agencies by exchanging threat information and operational details of cyber attacks, comparing intelligence, and sometimes litigating to contest government decisions to keep programs secret.).\n\n⁸⁴.     "International Law Studies\n\n2024\n\nIn the absence of full transparency, collaboration would appear to raise significant doubts about the neutrality of American tech and cyber security platforms.85 Have they embraced and implemented a neutral policy when encountering U.S. cyber operations (influence/espionage/defensive/offensive) directed against the interests of allied States, or even more so against American national security interests?86 What is the likelihood that American platforms would raise a red flag with any pertinent American national security authority whenever they detect, through their routine global work, what appears to be American cyber espionage, let alone offensive cyber operations?     "Collective Attribution in Cyberspace\n\nVol. 103\n\ncompanies that have joined Microsoft's initiative—the Cybersecurity Tech Accord—suggest that they will treat all governments equally, “giving no government preferential treatment or a free pass to attack users.”89 Kristen Eichensehr describes their neutrality approach as such that\n\nessentially means a most (or perhaps least) favored-nation approach to governments: there will be no exceptional treatment for the U.S., and companies will only do for the U.S. Government that which they are willing to do for all governments. Given the experience to date, should this policy be welcomed or re-evaluated? That is the question discussed below.\n\n## IV. COLLECTIVE ATTRIBUTION\n\nIn 2017, in the wake of two developments—the collapse of the fifth round of the UN–GGE and large-scale cyber attacks such as WannaCry and NotPetya—the United States and the United Kingdom extended the policy of official attribution to a new pattern of collective attribution aimed at deterring States from violating norms of responsible State behavior in cyberspace. As the table below shows, all the reviewed collective attributions, except one, relied on the national attribution processes of the United States and the United Kingdom regarding cyber attacks that targeted them or their allies. Prior to discussing the cumulative experience of the collective attribution concept per se, and to illustrate the complete picture in this context, the first section of this Part reviews three international initiatives that the United States introduced to deter States and advance responsible peacetime State behavior in cyberspace in conjunction with holding States accountable by relying on the concept of collective attribution.\n\n## A. Collective Attribution Within International Initiatives\n\nDespite the legal obstacles and instrumental ambiguity noted above, the List of Non-Binding Norms remains the main international instrument to hold States accountable for wrongdoing that violates the voluntary norms of responsible peacetime State behavior in cyberspace. This accountability is essential for establishing effective deterrence, while the attribution determination is a keystone for invoking accountability in any given incident.\n\nIn its updated National Cyber Strategy, the Trump Administration announced the launch of the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative to re\n\n2023), https://www.theregister.com/2023/09/20/huawei_china_claims/ (reporting on post of China’s Ministry of State Security on WeChat, in which the United States is accused of running cyber attacks and espionage for more than ten years against China, Russia, and forty-five other countries and regions, and of implanting backdoors in equipment and software and using American global technology brands to monitor and steal data).",
    "Collective Attribution in Cyberspace\n\nVol. 103\n\ninforce efforts to deter States from violating the List of Non-Binding Norms through “official attribution,” “collective attribution,” a “naming and shaming” strategy, and through a “collective response” by jointly imposing sanctions against States accused of violating the List.¹⁰⁹ Ultimately, no State has officially announced that it will join the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative, not even the closest ally of the United States, the United Kingdom, although it promptly endorsed the pillars of the U.S. strategy.¹¹⁰ The International Cyber Deterrence Initiative has not evolved into an effective international initiative, such as the Proliferation Security Initiative¹¹¹ or the International Counter Ransomware Initiative discussed below. In fact, the United States never officially launched the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative, and senior U.S. officials have rarely referred to it.¹¹²\n\nThe literature includes only one study that references the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative, focusing solely on the collective response rather than the credible collective attribution that is implicitly a prerequisite to any collective response.¹¹³ Within this study, the scholar examined the policy embraced by each State party in the FVEY in building offensive cyber capabilities. The findings reveal that the FVEY States, excluding New Zealand, align with the approach of responding firmly to irresponsible State behavior in cyberspace. This criminal hacking group is recognized as the world's most harmful cybercrime group. The outcomes of this operation included the seizure in three countries of LockBit's data exfiltration infrastructure by members of the task force. Two LockBit operatives were arrested in coordination with Europol. The U.S. Department of Justice unsealed indictments against two Russian citizens for conspiring to commit LockBit ransomware attacks. The Department of Justice also announced that two defendants responsible for using LockBit to execute ransomware attacks were in custody and would face trial in the United States. The lessons learned from this experience could prove valuable for the United States and the United Kingdom in addressing the pitfalls of the current collective attribution process and response. This could serve as a test case demonstrating how successful cooperation between International Counter Ransomware Initiative member States can be in fighting criminally motivated, as well as politically motivated, cybercrime. Thus, the Initiative, in particular, may serve as an appropriate pilot for exploring optional solutions to better tackle the challenges associated with collective attributions and responses. More importantly, such solutions would enhance State accountability and the effectiveness of attributions in changing State behavior in cyberspace.\n\n## B. The FVEY's attribution announcements are made concurrently and in coordination.¹²⁸ However, they rely on sharing classified information, not on the findings of an independent FVEY multinational investigative team or any other form of international investigative mechanism. Like the decision to officially attribute State responsibility itself, endorsing an official attribution made by another State is a political prerogative for each sovereign State, which may announce it as its own official attribution. Such attribution determinations rely on various cumulative considerations, including the accuracy and credibility of evidence shared with all partners. While Canada has, thus far, actively participated in all collective attributions initiated by the United States and the United Kingdom, Australia refrained in three instances (Cases 6, 7, 13) and New Zealand in four (Cases 6, 7, 11, 13). Neither New Zealand nor Australia publicly justified their decision to refrain in each of these instances.\n\n## ii. EU and NATO Attributions or Partial Attribution Statements\n\nThe EU, representing twenty-seven European States, has had a notable practice of declarations in support of collective attributions. Thus far, it participated in eleven out of fourteen collective attributions, while NATO participated in six out of these same eleven attributions. However, the attribution statements on behalf of the EU and NATO could hardly be considered fully attributive. Instead, they may be perceived as a partial attribution of responsibility, making a limited contribution to the collective attribution strategy.\n\n¹²⁷. See, e.g., Cases 5, 13, supra Section IV(B) (providing examples in which the United Kingdom assisted the Georgian authorities in contending with and investigating the malicious cyber campaign); see Press Release, U.S. Embassy Tirana, Committed Partners in Cyberspace: U.S. Concludes First Defensive Hunt Operation in Albania (Mar. 23, 2023), https://al.usembassy.gov/committed-partners-in-cyberspace-u-s-concludes-first-defensive-hunt-operation-in-albania/.\n\n¹²⁸.     "International Law Studies\n\n2024\n\nThe following are some probable causes driving this partial level of EU and NATO participation in collective attributions:\n\n(a) The EU and NATO do not possess independent cyber investigative capabilities. Both rely heavily on more capable allies, namely the United States and the United Kingdom. Furthermore, EU and NATO member States, like Sweden, the Netherlands, Estonia, Austria, France, and Germany, each of which possess independent investigative capabilities, allegedly provide the EU security authorities with “deficient and incomplete” evidence in order to preserve the confidentiality of their cyber capabilities.¹²⁹ To date, the EU has joined an official attribution initiated by one of its members only once (Case 10), and the attribution is highly questionable. NATO has never joined an attribution that was not initiated by the United States or the United Kingdom. It is worth noting that both States also face challenges in implementing a high degree of transparency with the EU security authorities due to the sensitivity and confidentiality of their intelligence sources. Nevertheless, the direct involvement of the United States and the United Kingdom in investigating cyber attacks appears to be a differentiating factor, possibly explaining why both, along with Canada and New Zealand, refrained from participating in the EU and Germany collective attribution (Case 10), while Australia settled for expressing solidarity.¹³⁰\n\n(b) The EU and NATO have joined collective attributions through brief declarations or statements issued on behalf of both Councils. The wording of these official declarations or statements must be cautious and measured to achieve unanimity within a truly brief period. Typically, they condemn the cyber attack in question, express concerns about it, and show solidarity with the affected States. The EU and NATO choose to avoid any explicit attribution of responsibility to the CRINK States. Shaping “Rules of the Road”\n\nAiming to bolster deterrence, the United States and the United Kingdom initiated the collective attribution process as a response to attacking States in cyberspace.[150] However, in the absence of normative clarity, attribution announcements refer to unacceptable and irresponsible State behavior, rather than specifying international rules or norms allegedly breached by the given cyber attack. Thus, the policy implemented usually involves delegitimization (\"naming and shaming\") and retorsions, lawful measures that can be imposed without the need for detailed legal justification. The objective is to shape \"rules of the road\" by specifying instances of unacceptable cyber activity on case-by-case bases and to develop State practice accordingly. This involves instilling among the entire community of nations the perspectives of collective attributors regarding which cyber operations may constitute irresponsible State behavior.[151] Such activities would be deemed irresponsible State behavior when conducted by official State agents or entities, as well as by hacking groups affiliated with these entities, operating under their instruction, direction, or control.[152] Although the List of Non-Binding Norms does not refer to economic or national security espionage, bilateral agreements and multinational commitments prohibit the theft of intellectual property (IP), trade secrets, and business information to gain competitive commercial advantages.[153] Such multinational commitments may be an additional source for shaping \"rules of the road\" in the commitments' context.\n\nThe cases reviewed can be categorized into subcategories representing types of irresponsible State behavior. Each subcategory has the potential to form specific prohibitions on certain types of conduct, akin to rules of the road. Below is a classification of the cases reviewed into four subcategories,\n\n150. THE WHITE HOUSE, supra note 12.\n151.     "International Law Studies\n\n2024\n\nactivity by States will bring greater clarity about when certain types of robust measures are justified in response.¹⁵⁸\n\nIn articulating this perspective using the norm of non-intervention, she recommends applying it to any State’s cyber activity that undermines another State’s ability to exercise control over matters that it is entitled to decide autonomously through the principle of State sovereignty. For additional clarity, she also suggests defining types of disruptive State cyber activities in various vulnerable sectors, such as energy security, essential medical care, economic stability, and democratic processes. Identifying a type of such cyber activity and examining it in its relevant context would determine whether it disrupts or denies another State’s ability to exercise its sovereign power to freely decide and act. If so, it would constitute a clear violation of the non-intervention norm, rendering it an unlawful activity. Since the UK Attorney General proposed this approach, the United States and the United Kingdom have jointly undertaken only two additional collective attributions (Cases 13, 14). However, instead of attributing unlawful cyber activities to Iran and Russia, the UK Foreign Secretary characterized Iranian actions as “reckless” and “unacceptable”¹⁵⁹ and Russian actions as “completely unacceptable.”¹⁶⁰ This aligns with the established practice of the FVEY, as evidenced in the cases reviewed. Nevertheless, adopting and implementing the British Attorney General’s integrated legal and political approach within the collective attribution strategy could potentially confer a more binding aspect to norms, such as the prohibitions on intervention and use of force, sovereignty of States, due diligence, and the boundaries of permitted espionage. This might create incentives for States, mindful of their reputation as responsible and law-abiding entities, to adhere to these norms as interpreted and applied to cyberspace. Furthermore, enforcing them through collective attribution and responses would be more consistent and coherent, thus, more effective in shaping State practice and international law.\n\n¹⁵⁸. Id.     "Collective Attribution in Cyberspace\n\nVol. 103\n\n## 4. Sanctions as a Collective Response\n\nAnother dimension of the legality of the attributed violation lies in the appropriate response. As mentioned earlier, both the FVEY and the EU confine their responses to retorsions, such as travel bans and asset freezing, undertaken against the entities and persons engaged in conducting the malicious cyber attacks in question. The expectation that a collective attribution would prompt retorsions from a high number of participating States, forming an effective collective deterrent response, has not materialized as of yet.¹⁶¹ Nevertheless, such a response has become a common practice of the United States and to a lesser extent, the EU and the FVEY.\n\nAt the level of the United States, sanctions are imposed with greater frequency against individuals and entities based on findings and charges detailed in joint advisories or unsealed indictments and law enforcement investigations. Despite the considerable number of sanctioned individuals and entities, many are government personnel and entities associated with the CRINK, and a significant number have also been indicted.¹⁶² While the ultimate goal of sanctions is not to punish but to bring about a positive change in behavior,¹⁶³ this change has not materialized as of yet. At the level of the FVEY partners, the United Kingdom has regulated its own independent cyber related sanctions regime and occasionally imposed sanctions in coordination with the United States.¹⁶⁴ Australia legislated a cyber sanctions law in December 2021. Nevertheless, the increasing frequency and scale of politically motivated cyber operations suggest that the deterring effect of collective attributions, along with retorsions, is weak.¹⁷² Due to the lack of authorized information regarding the outcomes of these sanctions and in the face of persistent politically motivated cyber attacks originating from the same culpable States and orchestrated by their governmental entities, it would not be inaccurate to argue that the effectiveness of this policy has yet to be conclusively demonstrated. Meanwhile, it still has a symbolic, declarative impact needed to emphasize the red lines that States should not cross.\n\nIn conclusion, at present, collective attribution is no more than the upshot of the national attribution process, mostly American and British, with the addition of evidence sharing with like-minded States, in a manner that imposes no burden on the U.S. or UK intelligence community. The United States and the United Kingdom are always the driving force, while a CRINK State almost always stands on the receiving end. States and alliances participating in collective attributions, particularly the EU and FVEY, do not determine whether to join the attribution through direct involvement in investigative and attribution processes, but rather are influenced by political affiliations and international commitments within international frameworks, such as the G7, G20, and U.S.-EU or UK-EU dialogues. As a result, the collectiveness as implemented in the attribution process does not bolster the credibility of the American or British attribution determinations. CONCLUSION\n\nMore than a decade has passed since Leon Panetta first used the metaphor of the Pearl Harbor attack to depict how serious and risky a cyber attack could be, warning “potential aggressors . . . that the United States has the capacity to locate them and to hold them accountable for their actions.” $^{174}$ Even graver and more precise warnings have been issued recurringly by U.S. presidents and senior officials in administrations since 2012. $^{175}$ President Biden, who during his first weeks in office had to handle a series of serious ransomware cyber operations originating in Russia that dealt a blow to U.S. public interests, announced: “I made it clear to President Putin . . . that the days of the United States rolling over in the face of Russia’s aggressive actions—interfering with our elections . . .—are over. We will not hesitate to raise the cost on Russia . . .” $^{176}$ In the same speech, the President emphasized that only nations “working together and in common” can solve “the accelerating global challenges.” He added, “we [the United States] cannot do it alone.” That is easier said than done in the international arena. Despite technological developments that have improved attribution capabilities, the international community has not yet established a binding legal framework for cyberspace. Instead, the United States, along with the United Kingdom, has chosen to build upon a national official attribution system by imposing collective attribution and responses to the wrongdoing, aiming to concurrently achieve two goals: (1) to reinforce State deterrence through public collective attribution and imposing costs; and (2) shaping and internalizing “rules of the road” for responsible State behavior in cyberspace. $^{177}$\n\n173. Id.\n177.     "Collective Attribution in Cyberspace\n\nVol. 103\n\nHowever, this article highlights fundamental flaws that impact the credibility and legitimacy of this attribution process and subsequently its effectiveness. The United States, as the major attributor, assigns responsibility to specific States without allowing transparency regarding the evidence, the criteria of selecting the cases, and maintaining ambiguity about the legal grounds on which their charges rely. Furthermore, since the attribution determination in any given case is not subject to external and objective scrutiny, it is hard to indicate impartiality, legality, coherency, and consistency in the process, which collapses into one measure—attribution, accusation, judging, and punishing by retorsions. This is a far cry from satisfying any \"right\" or \"fair process.\" Thus far, the overwhelming majority of collective attributions have been American-led. The participants are American governmental experts, in cooperation mostly with American tech platforms whose loyalty to American national security interests is not questioned. There is no effort to involve independent, reputable international experts in the process, which is not sufficiently transparent and, on the face of things, may be perceived as one-sided. At most, the American process may constitute an exchange of views and intelligence sharing with counterpart agencies in the FVEY.\n\nClose and clandestine cooperation—among the FVEY—and sharing information with the EU's relevant institutions, as well as with a few like-minded States, is not enough to replace a proper procedure that would lend credibility and legitimacy to the process and its outcomes. The absence of representative, impartial multinational experts in the process exacerbates the legitimacy gap. This is even more true when the State at the receiving end of the attribution process is always a rival State from the CRINK group. Such dynamics erode the process' legitimacy and may discourage States from embracing its findings and joining the collective attributions, let alone responses. Moreover, it can explain the ineffectiveness of international initiatives, such as the International Cyber Deterrence Initiative and Advancing Responsible State Behavior in Cyberspace, and the negligible effectiveness of the collective attributions. This article pointed to one initiative, the International Counter Ransomware Initiative, which, in my opinion, has the potential to become more effective in countering ransomware and cooperating in law enforcement once the ransomware is detected or when credible intelligence can anticipate the details of the upcom\n\nsignal to Russia without any reference to specific international rules about the cost Russia might pay if it continues with its destabilizing actions).\n\n331",
    "International Law Studies\n\n2024\n\ning cyber attack. The motive, whether political or criminal, does not matter when ransomware cripples major governmental services, even more so when it prompts States to declare an emergency, as happened in Costa Rica. $^{178}$  If the International Counter Ransomware Initiative proves itself effective, it could be part of a mechanism to tackle politically motivated cyber attacks by expanding its designation.\n\nThis article presents the considerable cumulative experience gained from destructive and disruptive State or State-sponsored cyber attacks and their accompanying attribution processes. This, coupled with the growing number of States expressing their perspectives in enduring public debates regarding the terms and boundaries for applying major international norms to cyberspace,[179] illustrate the image of a wide-open field that must be fenced in by further development and regulation. In my opinion, there is fertile ground for a justified reevaluation of the collective attribution process and the responses to cyber wrongdoing. This is critical to bolster the credibility, legitimacy, and subsequently the effectiveness of these collective attributions in shaping the rules of road and enhancing State accountability.\n\n178. WannaCry (May 2017)¹⁸⁰\n\nA ransomware cyber operation in which hundreds of thousands of computers were hacked and encrypted in over 150 States, causing serious economic damage and disrupting vital public services like healthcare, transportation, banks, etc.\n\nOn December 19, 2017, the United States and the United Kingdom led the FVEY members to attribute this cyber attack to North Korea, simultaneously and in coordination, constituting the first collective attribution. Shortly after, more than ten like-minded States joined this attribution.\n\nIn April 2018, the European Council published a statement of support, which included condemnation while avoiding clear identification of the culprit States. This declaration addressed both WannaCry and NotPetya.¹⁸¹\n\nIn September 2018, the U.S. Department of Justice indicted a North Korean hacker associated with Lazarus Group, which works for the North Korean Reconnaissance General Bureau.     "International Law Studies\n\n2024\n\n## 2. NotPetya (June 2017)¹⁸⁴\n\nThe NotPetya malware targeted Ukraine but spilled over to more than sixty States, including Russia. This malware acted as ransomware, causing enormous economic damage amounting to billions of dollars and serious disruptions in important public services. This cyber operation was politely motivated to damage Ukrainian businesses and sow public anger.\n\nIn February 2018, the FVEY collectively attributed this cyber attack to the GRU. Shortly after, more than fifteen like-minded States officially supported this attribution.¹⁸⁵ The U.S. Department of Justice indicted GRU officers involved in these cyber activities while the U.S. Department of Treasury imposed sanctions.\n\nIn July 2020, the EU approved sanctions against Unit 74455 of the GRU for the NotPetya cyber attack, the Lazarus group for the WannaCry attack, and against Russians and North Koreans who have been indicted in the United States.¹⁸⁶\n\n## 3. Hafnium Hack (Microsoft Exchange Server) (March 2021) 209\n\nIn July 2021, the United States, joined by the FVEY and Japan, attributed malicious cyber activity and irresponsible State behavior to China for stealing IP for commercial advantage and espionage through hackers contracted to the MSS (APT 31, APT 40). The EU statement did not assign direct responsibility to China but emphasized that the malicious cyber activities were undertaken from China's territory, urging it to prevent such activities.²¹⁰ The North Atlantic Council's statement \"acknowledges\" the statements made by the FVEY member States and expresses \"solidarity\" with those who were affected, calling on all States, \"including China,\" to uphold their international commitments.²¹¹\n\n10. Interference in European States' Democratic Processes (September 2021)\n\nOn September 24, 2021, shortly before the German elections, the EU High Representative denounced Russia for trying to interfere in European democratic processes by accessing computer systems and personal accounts in the EU member States and stealing data. The official statement relied on \"some EU member states\" that have observed malicious cyber activities, \"collectively designated as Ghostwriter and associated these with the Russian state.\"²¹² The statement asserts that such activities contradict the List of Non-Binding Norms, calling to immediately cease them and urging Russia to adhere to the List. It is the first and only case in which the EU independently initiated a statement that purported to express a collective attribution.\n\n209.     "Collective Attribution in Cyberspace\n\nVol. 103\n\n# 11. DDoS Attack Against Ukraine (February 15–16, 2022)\n\nA week prior to the Russian invasion, an unprecedented DDoS attack crashed Ukrainian banks and government websites. Although the head of the Cybersecurity Department of Security Service of Ukraine (SBU) said it was too early to identify specific perpetrators, Ukraine pointed the finger at Russia as the only country interested in destabilizing Ukraine.[213] Forty-eight hours later, the United States, United Kingdom, Canada, and Australia collectively blamed Russia for conducting the operation through its GRU. This collective attribution is exceptional primarily for one reason: It is the fastest political decision made to date officially attributing State responsibility.\n\n# 12. Blocking the KA-SAT Network (February 16, 2022)\n\nOn May 10, 2022, the United Kingdom's National Cyber Security Centre assessed that Russia's GRU was almost certainly responsible for the cyber attack against ViaSat, a multinational communications provider, one hour prior to the Russian invasion of Ukraine. This cyber attack, which is believed to have targeted the KA-SAT network to disrupt or cut off Ukraine's military communication, spilled over to civilian customers in Ukraine and across Europe, making tens of thousands of terminals inoperable in a manner that was irreversible. Cyber Attacks Targeting Albanian Governmental Websites (July 15, 2022)\n\nOn September 7, 2022, Albania severed diplomatic relations with Iran. The reason for such a serious response was a major cyber-campaign conducted against it nearly two months earlier. This campaign targeted significant Albanian government websites, including websites for providing essential public services and websites of the Albanian Parliament and Prime Minister's office.[218] Consequently, essential websites were shut down, and governmental data, including sensitive emails, were leaked. Although Albania is a NATO member State, it has not applied to activate Article 5 of the North Atlantic Treaty. Albania is not a cyber-power State. Therefore, it appealed to the United States, United Kingdom, and other capable States to investigate these cyber attacks and assist in ensuring resiliency. The United States, United Kingdom, and Canada have attributed State responsibility to Iran, while the EU and NATO have not deviated from their cautious path, avoiding explicit attribution statements.[219]\n\nIn September 2020, the U.S. Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control designated Iran's Ministry of Intelligence and Security and its Minister of Intelligence as engaging in cyber-enabled activities against the United States and its allies.[220]\n\n14.
